<p><b>Ukraine</b> (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Ð£ÐºÑÐ°ÑÐ½Ð°</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian" title="Romanization of Ukrainian">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Ukrainian-language romanization"><i lang="uk-Latn">UkraÃ¯na</i></span>, <small>pronounced </small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Ukrainian" title="Help:IPA/Ukrainian">[ÊkrÉËjinÉ]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uk-%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B0_(2).oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/be/Uk-%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B0_%282%29.oga" class="internal" title="Uk-Ð£ÐºÑÐ°ÑÐ½Ð° (2).oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>) is a <a href="/wiki/Country" title="Country">country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">second largest country in Europe</a> after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> which borders it to the east and north-east.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[a]</a></sup> Ukraine also shares borders with <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[b]</a></sup> to the south; and has a coastline along the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>. It covers about 600,000 km<sup>2</sup> (230,000 sq mi),<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[c]</a></sup> with a population of about 40 million.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[d]</a></sup> The nation's capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Ukraine" title="List of cities in Ukraine">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (ÐÐ¸ÑÐ²; <a href="/wiki/KyivNotKiev" title="KyivNotKiev">previously Kiev</a>). The official and national language is <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>, and most people are also <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine" title="Russian language in Ukraine">fluent in Russian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[15]</a></sup> Ukraine has been independent since 1991 and its current president is <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a>.
</p><p>The territory of modern Ukraine has been inhabited since 32,000 BC. During the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the area was a key centre of <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> culture under <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>, which was ultimately destroyed by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'">Mongol invasion</a> in the 13th century. Over the next 600 years, the area was contested, divided, and ruled by external powers, including the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Austrian Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a> emerged in <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a> in the 17th century but was partitioned between Russia and Poland, and ultimately completely absorbed by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>. The 19th century saw the growth of Ukrainian nationalism, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia_and_Lodomeria" title="Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria">Galicia</a>, then part of <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>. In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> a Ukrainian national movement re-emerged, and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> was formed in 1917. This short-lived state was <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Ukrainian_War" title="SovietâUkrainian War">forcibly reconstituted</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, which became a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> (USSR) in 1922. From 1932 to 1933 the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> killed millions of Ukrainians. In 1939, <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> was <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">annexed</a> from Poland by the USSR. Ukraine was the most populous and industrialised republic after the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Soviet Republic">Russian Soviet Republic</a>.
</p><p>Ukraine regained its independence in 1991 with the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>. Since its independence, Ukraine has been governed as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary republic</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a>. It declared itself a <a href="/wiki/Neutral_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Neutral state">neutral state</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-gska2.rada.gov.ua_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gska2.rada.gov.ua-20">[16]</a></sup> forming a limited military partnership with Russia and other <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS countries</a> while also establishing a <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">partnership with NATO</a> in 1994. In 2013, mass protests and demonstrations known as the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> erupted, escalating into the <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a> that led to the establishment of a new government. These events led to Russia <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexing Crimea</a> and a <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas" title="War in Donbas">war in Donbas</a> against Russian-backed separatists, culminating in a <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion</a> in February 2022. Ukraine has continued seeking closer economic, political, and military ties with the West (particularly <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>) amid ongoing <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">war with Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine-21">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine is among the poorest countries in Europe and suffers from widespread <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Ukraine" title="Corruption in Ukraine">corruption</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-transparency_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transparency-22">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-poor_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poor-23">[19]</a></sup> However, due to its extensive fertile land, pre-war Ukraine was one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Grain_trade" title="Grain trade">grain exporters</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-grain1_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grain1-24">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-grain2_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grain2-25">[21]</a></sup> It is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, the <a href="/wiki/GUAM_Organization_for_Democracy_and_Economic_Development" title="GUAM Organization for Democracy and Economic Development">GUAM organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Association_Trio" title="Association Trio">Association Trio</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Lublin_Triangle" title="Lublin Triangle">Lublin Triangle</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_orthography">Etymology and orthography</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">Name of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>There are different hypotheses as to the etymological origins of the <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">name of <i>Ukraine</i></a>. The most widespread hypothesis theorizes that it comes from the <a href="/wiki/Old_Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Slavic">old Slavic</a> term for "<a href="/wiki/Borderland" class="mw-disambig" title="Borderland">borderland</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> as does the word <i><a href="/wiki/Krajina" title="Krajina">krajina</a></i>.
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="the_Ukraine"></span>During most of the 20th century, Ukraine (whether independent or not) was referred to in the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a> prefaced with the <a href="/wiki/Definite_article" class="mw-redirect" title="Definite article">definite article</a>, i.e., "the Ukraine".<sup id="cite_ref-merriam-webster_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-merriam-webster-27">[23]</a></sup> This is because the word <i>ukraina</i> means "borderland"<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup> and so an article would be natural in the English language; this is similar to "<i><span title="Dutch-language text"><i lang="nl">Nederlanden</i></span></i>", which means "low lands" and is rendered in English as "<i>the</i> <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup> However, since Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_of_Ukraine" title="Declaration of Independence of Ukraine">declaration of independence</a> in 1991, the use of the definite article in the name has become politicized and is now rarer, and <a href="/wiki/Style_guide" title="Style guide">style guides</a> advise against its use.<sup id="cite_ref-UKrW812991TU_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKrW812991TU-30">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup> According to US ambassador <a href="/wiki/William_B._Taylor,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="William B. Taylor, Jr.">William Taylor</a>, as of the 2010s using "the Ukraine" implies disregard for Ukrainian sovereignty.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> The official Ukrainian position is that "the Ukraine" is incorrect, both grammatically and politically.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_Magazine_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News_Magazine-33">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ukraine" title="History of Ukraine">History of Ukraine</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pektoral111.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pektoral111.JPG/200px-Pektoral111.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="191" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pektoral111.JPG/300px-Pektoral111.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pektoral111.JPG/400px-Pektoral111.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1233" data-file-height="1176"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pektoral111.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A gold <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythian</a> neckpiece, from a royal <a href="/wiki/Kurgan" title="Kurgan">kurgan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pokrov,_Ukraine" title="Pokrov, Ukraine">Pokrov</a> (4th century BC).</div></div></div>
<p>Settlement by <a href="/wiki/Modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern humans">modern humans</a> in Ukraine and its vicinity dates back to 32,000 BC, with evidence of the <a href="/wiki/Gravettian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Gravettian culture">Gravettian culture</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Mountains" title="Crimean Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-orig_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orig-34">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-35">[31]</a></sup> By 4,500 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> <a href="/wiki/Cucuteni%E2%80%93Trypillia_culture" title="CucuteniâTrypillia culture">CucuteniâTrypillia culture</a> was flourishing in wide areas of modern Ukraine, including <a href="/wiki/Trypillia" title="Trypillia">Trypillia</a> and the entire <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>-<a href="/wiki/Dniester" title="Dniester">Dniester</a> region. Ukraine is also considered to be the likely location of the first <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_the_horse" title="Domestication of the horse">domestication of the horse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cbc.ca_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbc.ca-39">[35]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>, the land was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scythians" title="Scythians">Scythians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sarmatians" title="Sarmatians">Sarmatians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup> Between 700 BC and 200 BC it was part of the <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythian</a> kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 6th century BC, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> colonies were established on the north-eastern shore of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>, such as at <a href="/wiki/Tyras" title="Tyras">Tyras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olbia,_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Olbia, Ukraine">Olbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chersonesus" title="Chersonesus">Chersonesus</a>. These thrived into the 6th century AD. The <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Goths</a> stayed in the area, but came under the sway of the <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a> from the 370s. In the 7th century, the territory that is now eastern Ukraine was the centre of <a href="/wiki/Old_Great_Bulgaria" title="Old Great Bulgaria">Old Great Bulgaria</a>. At the end of the century, the majority of Bulgar tribes migrated in different directions, and the <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a> took over much of the land.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 5th and 6th centuries, the <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Early Slavic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antes_(people)" class="mw-redirect" title="Antes (people)">Antes people</a> lived in Ukraine. The Antes were the ancestors of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>: <a href="/wiki/White_Croats" title="White Croats">White Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Severians" title="Severians">Severians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polans_(eastern)" title="Polans (eastern)">Eastern Polans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drevlyans" class="mw-redirect" title="Drevlyans">Drevlyans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dulebes" title="Dulebes">Dulebes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ulichians" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulichians">Ulichians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tiverians" class="mw-redirect" title="Tiverians">Tiverians</a>. Migrations from the territories of present-day Ukraine throughout the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> established many <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">South Slavic</a> nations. Northern migrations, reaching almost to <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ilmen" title="Lake Ilmen">Lake Ilmen</a>, led to the emergence of the <a href="/wiki/Ilmen_Slavs" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilmen Slavs">Ilmen Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krivichs" title="Krivichs">Krivichs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radimichs" title="Radimichs">Radimichs</a>, the groups ancestral to the <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>. Following an <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Avars" title="Pannonian Avars">Avar</a> raid in 602 and the collapse of the Antes Union, most of these peoples survived as separate tribes until the beginning of the second millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (March 2022)">need quotation to verify</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Golden_Age_of_Kyiv">Golden Age of Kyiv</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ruthenia" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Ruthenia">Kingdom of Ruthenia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_(1054-1132).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/260px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="347" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/390px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/520px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="770" data-file-height="1028"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_(1054-1132).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The furthest extent of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>, 1054â1132.</div></div></div>
<p>The establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a> remains obscure and uncertain; there are at least three versions depending on interpretations of the chronicles.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup> In general, the state included much of present-day Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-45">[41]</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a></i> the Rus' elite and rulers initially consisted of <a href="/wiki/Varangian" class="mw-redirect" title="Varangian">Varangians</a> from <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup> In 882, the pagan <a href="/wiki/Oleg_of_Novgorod" title="Oleg of Novgorod">Prince Oleg</a> (Oleh) conquered <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> from <a href="/wiki/Askold_and_Dir" title="Askold and Dir">Askold and Dir</a> and proclaimed it as the capital of the Rus'.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> However, it also believed that the East Slavic tribes along the southern parts of the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper River</a> were already in the process of forming a state independently.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 10th and 11th centuries, Kievan Rus' became the largest and most powerful state in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-49">[45]</a></sup> The Varangians later assimilated into the Slavic population and became part of the first Rus' dynasty, the <a href="/wiki/Rurik_dynasty" title="Rurik dynasty">Rurik dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-45">[41]</a></sup> Kievan Rus' was composed of several <a href="/wiki/Principality" title="Principality">principalities</a> ruled by the interrelated Rurikid <i><a href="/wiki/Knyaz" title="Knyaz">kniazes</a></i> ("princes"), who often fought each other for possession of Kyiv.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Golden Age of Kievan Rus' began with the reign of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Vladimir the Great</a> (980â1015), who <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus'">turned Rus' toward Byzantine Christianity</a>. During the reign of his son, <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> (1019â1054), Kievan Rus' reached the zenith of its cultural development and military power.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_45-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-45">[41]</a></sup> The state soon fragmented as the relative importance of regional powers rose again. After a final resurgence under the rule of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_II_Monomakh" title="Vladimir II Monomakh">Vladimir II Monomakh</a> (1113â1125) and his son <a href="/wiki/Mstislav_I_of_Kiev" title="Mstislav I of Kiev">Mstislav</a> (1125â1132), Kievan Rus' finally disintegrated into separate principalities following Mstislav's death.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 13th-century <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus'">Mongol invasion</a> devastated Kievan Rus' and Kyiv was completely <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kyiv_(1240)" class="mw-redirect" title="Siege of Kyiv (1240)">destroyed in 1240</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[48]</a></sup> On today's Ukrainian territory, the principalities of <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Halych" title="Principality of Halych">Halych</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volodymyr-Volynskyi</a> arose, and were merged into the state of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia" title="Kingdom of GaliciaâVolhynia">GaliciaâVolhynia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_of_Galicia" title="Daniel of Galicia">Daniel of Galicia</a>, son of <a href="/wiki/Roman_the_Great" title="Roman the Great">Roman the Great</a>, re-united much of south-western Rus', including Volhynia, Galicia and the ancient capital of Kyiv. He was subsequently crowned by the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">papal</a> <a href="/wiki/Archbishop" title="Archbishop">archbishop</a> as the first <a href="/wiki/Monarch" title="Monarch">king</a> of the newly created <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ruthenia" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Ruthenia">Kingdom of Ruthenia</a> in 1253.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_domination">Foreign domination</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Crown of the Kingdom of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/220px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/330px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/440px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1410" data-file-height="1109"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a> at its maximum extent in 1619. <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Polish Crown</a> exercised power over much of Ukraine since <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">1569</a> and rejected the Ukrainian call for autonomy.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1349, Ruthenia ceased to exist as an independent entity in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia_Wars" title="GaliciaâVolhynia Wars">GaliciaâVolhynia Wars</a>, with its lands partitioned between the <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Kingdom of Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rowell266_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rowell266-55">[51]</a></sup> From the mid-13th century to the late 1400s the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a> founded numerous colonies in the Black Sea region of modern Ukraine and transformed these into large commercial centers headed by the consul, a representative of the Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup> In 1430, the region of <a href="/wiki/Podolia" title="Podolia">Podolia</a> was incorporated into Poland and Ukraine became increasingly settled by Polish colonisers.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup> In 1441, <a href="/wiki/Genghisid" class="mw-redirect" title="Genghisid">Genghisid</a> prince <a href="/wiki/Haci_I_Giray" class="mw-redirect" title="Haci I Giray">Haci I Giray</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Crimean Peninsula">Crimean Peninsula</a> and the surrounding steppes;<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> the Khanate orchestrated <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatar</a> <a href="/wiki/Crimean%E2%80%93Nogai_slave_raids_in_Eastern_Europe" title="CrimeanâNogai slave raids in Eastern Europe">slave raids</a> and took an estimated two million Ruthenian slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1569 the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>, and most of the former Ruthenian lands were transferred from Lithuania to the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Crown of the Kingdom of Poland</a>, becoming <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> Polish territory. Under the pressures of <a href="/wiki/Polonisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonisation">Polonisation</a>, many landed gentry of <a href="/wiki/Ruthenia" title="Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a> converted to <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Catholicism</a> and joined the circles of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_nobility" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish nobility">Polish nobility</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup> 
</p><p>Deprived of native protectors among Rus nobility, the peasants and townspeople began turning for protection to the emerging <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Cossacks" title="Zaporozhian Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a>. In the mid-17th century, a Cossack military quasi-state, the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Host" title="Zaporozhian Host">Zaporozhian Host</a>, was formed by <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_Cossacks" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper Cossacks">Dnieper Cossacks</a> and Ruthenian peasants.<sup id="cite_ref-zaporizhia_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zaporizhia-62">[58]</a></sup> Poland exercised little real control over this population, but found the Cossacks to be useful against the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Turks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Tatars</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-britcos_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britcos-63">[59]</a></sup> and at times the two were allies in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_wars_in_Europe" title="Ottoman wars in Europe">military campaigns</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> However, the continued harsh <a href="/wiki/Serf" class="mw-redirect" title="Serf">enserfment</a> of Ruthenian peasantry by Polish overlords and the suppression of the Orthodox Church alienated the Cossacks.<sup id="cite_ref-britcos_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britcos-63">[59]</a></sup> The Cossacks did not shy from taking up arms against those they perceived as enemies and occupiers, including the Polish Catholic state with its local representatives.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cossack_Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg/170px-Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg/255px-Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg/340px-Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1116" data-file-height="1662"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hondius_Bohdan_Khmelnytsky.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hetmans_of_Ukrainian_Cossacks" title="Hetmans of Ukrainian Cossacks">Hetman</a> <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a> established an independent <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack state</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">1648 uprising</a> against Poland.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1648, <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">largest of the Cossack uprisings</a> against the Commonwealth and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">Polish king</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> After Khmelnytsky made an entry into Kyiv in 1648, where he was hailed liberator of the people from Polish captivity, he founded the <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a>, which existed until 1764 (some sources claim until 1782).<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup> After Khmelnytsky suffered a crushing defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berestechko" title="Battle of Berestechko">Battle of Berestechko</a> in 1651, and turned to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_monarchs" title="List of Russian monarchs">Russian tsar</a> for help. In 1654, Khmelnytsky was subject to the <a href="/wiki/Pereyaslav_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="Pereyaslav Council">Pereyaslav Council</a>, forming a military and political alliance with Russia that acknowledged loyalty to the Russian monarch.
</p><p>In the period 1657â1686 came "<a href="/wiki/The_Ruin_(Ukrainian_history)" title="The Ruin (Ukrainian history)">The Ruin</a>", a devastating 30-year war amongst Russia, Poland, the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossacks</a> for control of the Cossack Hetmanate. The wars escalated in intensity with hundreds of thousands of deaths. The "<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Perpetual_Peace_(1686)" title="Treaty of Perpetual Peace (1686)">Treaty of Perpetual Peace</a>" between Russia and Poland in 1686 divided the lands of the Cossack Hetmanate between them, reducing the portion over which Poland had claimed sovereignty. In 1686, the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitanate_of_Kyiv" title="Metropolitanate of Kyiv">Metropolitanate of Kyiv</a> was <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_the_Metropolitanate_of_Kyiv_by_the_Moscow_Patriarchate" title="Annexation of the Metropolitanate of Kyiv by the Moscow Patriarchate">annexed by the Moscow Patriarchate</a> through a synodal letter of the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople</a> <a href="/wiki/Dionysius_IV_of_Constantinople" title="Dionysius IV of Constantinople">Dionysius IV</a>, thus placing the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitanate_of_Kyiv#Orthodox_Church_of_Ukraine" title="Metropolitanate of Kyiv">Metropolitanate of Kyiv</a> under the authority of <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>.
</p><p>In 1709, Cossack Hetman <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Mazepa" title="Ivan Mazepa">Ivan Mazepa</a> (1639â1709) defected to <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> against Russia in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700â1721).<sup id="cite_ref-Magocsi_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Magocsi-68">[64]</a></sup> Eventually Tsar <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter</a> recognized that to consolidate and modernize Russia's political and economic power it was necessary to do away with the Cossack Hetmanate as well as the Ukrainian and Cossack aspirations to autonomy.<sup id="cite_ref-Magocsi_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Magocsi-68">[64]</a></sup> Mazepa died in exile after fleeing from the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava" title="Battle of Poltava">Battle of Poltava</a> (1709), in which the Swedes and their Cossack allies suffered a catastrophic defeat.<sup id="cite_ref-Magocsi_68-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Magocsi-68">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/220px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/330px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/440px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2293" data-file-height="1441"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russia's victory over <a href="/wiki/Charles_XII_of_Sweden" title="Charles XII of Sweden">Charles XII of Sweden</a> and his ally <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Mazepa" title="Ivan Mazepa">Ivan Mazepa</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava" title="Battle of Poltava">Battle of Poltava</a> (1709) destroyed <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> autonomy.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1768, the Cossacks led yet another anti-Polish uprising, called <a href="/wiki/Koliivshchyna" title="Koliivshchyna">Koliivshchyna</a>, killing tens of thousands of Poles and Jews who settled Ukraine in the previous centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> Religious warfare also broke out between two Ukrainian groups. Increasing conflict between the <a href="/wiki/Ruthenian_Uniate_Church" title="Ruthenian Uniate Church">Ruthenian Uniate Church</a> and Orthodox parishes along the newly reinforced Polish-Russian border on the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a> eventually led to the uprising. Faith also reflected the opposing Polish (Western Catholic) and Russian (Eastern Orthodox) political allegiances.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the years 1764-1781, <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a> incorporated much of <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> when the <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Sich" title="Zaporozhian Sich">Zaporozhian Sich</a> were abolished. After the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Empire" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Empire">annexation of Crimea by Russia</a> in 1783, the newly acquired lands, now called <a href="/wiki/Novorossiya" title="Novorossiya">Novorossiya</a> were opened up to settlement by Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tsarist_autocracy" title="Tsarist autocracy">tsarist autocracy</a> established a policy of <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a>, suppressing the use of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian language</a> and curtailing the Ukrainian national identity.<sup id="cite_ref-censor_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censor-72">[68]</a></sup> The western part of present-day Ukraine was subsequently split between Russia and <a href="/wiki/Habsburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Habsburg">Habsburg</a>-ruled <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Austria</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">fall</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a> in 1795.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_and_early_20th_century">19th and early 20th century</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Krai" title="Southwestern Krai">Southwestern Krai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kharkov_Governorate" title="Kharkov Governorate">Kharkov Governorate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chernigov_Governorate" title="Chernigov Governorate">Chernigov Governorate</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_during_World_War_I" title="Ukraine during World War I">Ukraine during World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_after_the_Russian_Revolution" title="Ukraine after the Russian Revolution">Ukraine after the Russian Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_War_of_Independence" title="Ukrainian War of Independence">Ukrainian War of Independence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Ukrainian_War" title="SovietâUkrainian War">SovietâUkrainian War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/220px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/330px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/440px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="873"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kiev_Offensive_(1920)" title="Kiev Offensive (1920)">Polish troops enter Kyiv</a> in May 1920 during the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="PolishâSoviet War">PolishâSoviet War</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Riga" title="Peace of Riga">Peace of Riga</a> signed on 18 March 1921, Poland took control of modern-day western Ukraine while Soviets took control of eastern and central Ukraine.</div></div></div>
<p>Beginning in the 19th century, there was migration from Ukraine to distant areas of the Russian Empire. According to the 1897 census, there were 223,000 ethnic Ukrainians in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> and 102,000 in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[69]</a></sup> An additional 1.6 million emigrated to the east in the ten years after the opening of the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> in 1906.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Far Eastern</a> areas with an ethnic Ukrainian population became known as <a href="/wiki/Green_Ukraine" title="Green Ukraine">Green Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 19th century saw the rise of Ukrainian nationalism, particularly in Austrian <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(eastern_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (eastern Europe)">Galicia</a> under the relatively lenient rule of the <a href="/wiki/Habsburgs" class="mw-redirect" title="Habsburgs">Habsburgs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> With growing urbanization and modernization, and a cultural trend toward <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">romantic nationalism</a>, a Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Intelligentsia" title="Intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> committed to national rebirth and social justice emerged. The serf-turned-national-poet <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> (1814â1861) and the political theorist <a href="/wiki/Mykhailo_Drahomanov" title="Mykhailo Drahomanov">Mykhailo Drahomanov</a> (1841â1895) led the growing nationalist movement.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukrainians entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of both the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>, under Austria, and the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>, under Russia. Around 3.5 million Ukrainians fought with the <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Imperial_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Military history of Imperial Russia">Imperial Russian Army</a>, while 250,000 fought for the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_War_of_Independence" title="Ukrainian War of Independence">War of Independence</a>, the short-lived <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> was proclaimed on 23 June 1917. The Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a> (or Soviet Ukraine) successively established territories in the former Russian Empire; while the <a href="/wiki/West_Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="West Ukrainian People's Republic">West Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hutsul_Republic" title="Hutsul Republic">Hutsul Republic</a> emerged briefly in the Ukrainian lands of former Austro-Hungarian territory.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Ukrainian_War" title="PolishâUkrainian War">PolishâUkrainian War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="PolishâSoviet War">PolishâSoviet War</a>, western Ukraine was incorporated into <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a> was formed in lands annexed by the Bolsheviks (1921 <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Riga" title="Peace of Riga">Peace of Riga</a>). Modern-day <a href="/wiki/Bukovina" title="Bukovina">Bukovina</a> was occupied by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Romania" title="Kingdom of Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Ruthenia" title="Carpathian Ruthenia">Carpathian Ruthenia</a> was admitted to <a href="/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic" title="First Czechoslovak Republic">Czechoslovakia</a> as an autonomy.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[77]</a></sup> In Poland, the Polish government openly propagated <a href="/wiki/Anti-Ukrainian_sentiment" title="Anti-Ukrainian sentiment">anti-Ukrainian sentiment</a> and restricted rights of people who declared Ukrainian nationality and belonged to the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-82">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-83">[79]</a></sup> In consequence, an underground Ukrainian nationalist and militant movement arose in the 1920s and 1930s, which gradually transformed into the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Military_Organization" title="Ukrainian Military Organization">Ukrainian Military Organization</a> and later the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Ukrainian_Nationalists" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists">Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists</a> (OUN).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Inter-war_Soviet_Ukraine">Inter-war Soviet Ukraine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/220px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/330px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/440px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1188"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A starved man on the streets of <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, 1933. <a href="/wiki/Collectivization" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivization">Collectivization</a> of crops and their confiscation by Soviet authorities led to a major famine in Soviet Ukraine known as the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> devastated the whole <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> including eastern and central Ukraine. It left over 1.5 million people dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the former Russian Empire territory. Soviet Ukraine also faced the <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian famine of 1921">Russian famine of 1921</a> (primarily affecting the Russian <a href="/wiki/Volga_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga Region">Volga</a>-<a href="/wiki/Ural_(region)" title="Ural (region)">Ural</a> region).<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[81]</a></sup> During the 1920s,<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[82]</a></sup> under the Ukrainisation policy pursued by the national Communist leadership of <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Skrypnyk" title="Mykola Skrypnyk">Mykola Skrypnyk</a>, Soviet leadership encouraged a national renaissance in <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Culture of Ukraine">Ukrainian culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">language</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a> was part of the Soviet-wide policy of <a href="/wiki/Korenisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Korenisation">Korenisation</a> (literally <i>indigenisation</i>). Starting from the late 1920s with a <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">centrally planned economy</a>, Soviet Ukraine took part in an <a href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrialization in the USSR">industrialisation scheme</a> which quadrupled its industrial output during the 1930s.
</p><p>During the early Soviet period, the Ukrainian peasantry suffered from the <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivization in the USSR">programme of collectivization</a> of agricultural crops. Collectivization was part of the <a href="/wiki/First_five-year_plan" title="First five-year plan">first five-year plan</a> and was enforced by regular troops and the secret police known as <a href="/wiki/Cheka" title="Cheka">Cheka</a>. Those who resisted were <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">arrested and deported</a> to <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">gulags</a> and work camps. As members of the collective farms were sometimes not allowed to receive any grain until unrealistic quotas were met, millions starved to death in a <a href="/wiki/Droughts_and_famines_in_Russia_and_the_Soviet_Union" title="Droughts and famines in Russia and the Soviet Union">famine</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> or the "Great Famine", which was recognized by some countries as an act of <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> perpetrated by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> and other Soviet notables.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup> Largely the same groups were responsible for the mass killing operations during the civil war, collectivization, and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Terror</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front (World War II)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ukraine" title="Reichskommissariat Ukraine">Reichskommissariat Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Ukraine" title="The Holocaust in Ukraine">The Holocaust in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine-growth.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/300px-Ukraine-growth.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="178" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/450px-Ukraine-growth.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/600px-Ukraine-growth.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="475"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine-growth.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The territorial evolution of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>, 1922â1954</div></div></div>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a> in September 1939, <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet</a> troops divided the territory of Poland. Thus, Eastern <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Eastern_Europe)" title="Galicia (Eastern Europe)">Galicia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volhynia</a> with their Ukrainian population became part of Ukraine. For the first time in history, the nation was united.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1940, the Soviets annexed <a href="/wiki/Bessarabia" title="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> and northern <a href="/wiki/Bukovina" title="Bukovina">Bukovina</a>. The Ukrainian SSR incorporated the northern and southern districts of Bessarabia, Northern Bukovina, and the <a href="/wiki/Hertsa_region" title="Hertsa region">Hertsa region</a>. But it ceded the western part of the <a href="/wiki/Moldavian_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic">Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic</a> to the newly created <a href="/wiki/Moldavian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic">Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>. These territorial gains of the USSR were internationally recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaties,_1947" title="Paris Peace Treaties, 1947">Paris peace treaties of 1947</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg" 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg/360px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1553" data-file-height="2096"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Marshal <a href="/wiki/Semyon_Timoshenko" title="Semyon Timoshenko">Timoshenko</a> (born in the <a href="/wiki/Budjak" title="Budjak">Budjak</a> region) commanded numerous fronts throughout the war, including the <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Front_(Soviet_Union)" title="Southwestern Front (Soviet Union)">Southwestern Front</a> east of Kyiv in 1941.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">German armies</a> <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a> on 22 June 1941, initiating nearly four years of <a href="/wiki/Total_war" title="Total war">total war</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis</a> initially advanced against desperate but unsuccessful efforts of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a>. In the encirclement <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(1941)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kyiv (1941)">battle of Kyiv</a>, the city was acclaimed as a "<a href="/wiki/Hero_City_(Soviet_Union)" title="Hero City (Soviet Union)">Hero City</a>", because of its fierce <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(1941)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kyiv (1941)">resistance</a>. More than 600,000 Soviet soldiers (or one-quarter of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Western_Front" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Western Front">Soviet Western Front</a>) were killed or taken captive there, with many suffering <a href="/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war" class="mw-redirect" title="German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war">severe mistreatment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the majority of Ukrainians fought in or alongside the Red Army and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_partisans" title="Soviet partisans">Soviet resistance</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-worldwars_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldwars-93">[89]</a></sup> in Western Ukraine an independent <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Insurgent_Army" title="Ukrainian Insurgent Army">Ukrainian Insurgent Army</a> movement arose (UPA, 1942). It was created as the armed forces of the underground <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ukrainian_Nationalists" title="Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists">Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists</a> (OUN).<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vedeneyev_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vedeneyev-95">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both organizations, the OUN and the UPA, supported the goal of an <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Ukrainian_Independence,_1941" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration of Ukrainian Independence, 1941">independent Ukrainian state</a> on the territory with a Ukrainian ethnic majority. Although this brought conflict with Nazi Germany, at times the <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Atanasovych_Melnyk" title="Andriy Atanasovych Melnyk">Melnyk</a> wing of the OUN allied with the Nazi forces. From mid-1943 until the end of the war the UPA carried out <a href="/wiki/Massacres_of_Poles_in_Volhynia_and_Eastern_Galicia" title="Massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia">massacres of ethnic Poles</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volhynia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Galicia" title="Eastern Galicia">Eastern Galicia</a> regions, killing around 100,000 Polish civilians,<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[92]</a></sup> which brought reprisals.<sup id="cite_ref-IPNconf_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPNconf-97">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>These organized massacres were an attempt by the OUN to create a homogeneous Ukrainian state without a Polish minority living within its borders, and to prevent the post-war Polish state from asserting its sovereignty over areas that had been part of pre-war Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> After the war, the UPA continued to fight the USSR until the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[96]</a></sup> At the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Liberation_Army" title="Ukrainian Liberation Army">Ukrainian Liberation Army</a>, another nationalist movement, fought alongside the Nazis.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/220px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/330px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/440px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1925" data-file-height="1223"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> suffered significant damage during <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">World War II</a>, and was occupied by the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Germans</a> from 19 September 1941 until 6 November 1943.</div></div></div>
<p>In total, the number of ethnic Ukrainians who fought in the ranks of the Soviet Army is estimated from 4.5 million<sup id="cite_ref-worldwars_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldwars-93">[89]</a></sup> to 7 million.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_C1"><a href="#endnote_C1">[c]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Partisans" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Partisans">pro-Soviet partisan</a> guerrilla resistance in Ukraine is estimated at 47,800 from the start of occupation to 500,000 at its peak in 1944, with about 50% being ethnic Ukrainians.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> Generally, the Ukrainian Insurgent Army's figures are unreliable, with figures ranging anywhere from 15,000 to as many as 100,000 fighters.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the Ukrainian SSR was organised within the <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ukraine" title="Reichskommissariat Ukraine">Reichskommissariat Ukraine</a>, with the intention of exploiting its resources and eventual German settlement. Some western Ukrainians, who had only joined the Soviet Union in 1939, hailed the Germans as liberators. Brutal German rule eventually turned their supporters against the Nazi administrators, who made little attempt to exploit dissatisfaction with Stalinist policies.<sup id="cite_ref-ww2_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ww2-105">[101]</a></sup> Instead, the Nazis preserved the collective-farm system, carried out <a href="/wiki/Mass_graves_in_the_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Mass graves in the Soviet Union">genocidal policies</a> against <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Ukraine" title="History of the Jews in Ukraine">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/OST-Arbeiter" class="mw-redirect" title="OST-Arbeiter">deported millions of people to work in Germany</a>, and began a depopulation program to prepare for German colonisation.<sup id="cite_ref-ww2_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ww2-105">[101]</a></sup> They blockaded the transport of food on the Kyiv River.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>The vast majority of the fighting in World War II took place on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> By some estimates, 93% of all German casualties took place there.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">total losses</a> inflicted upon the Ukrainian population during the war are estimated at 6 million,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dt-kul-dem-los_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dt-kul-dem-los-110">[106]</a></sup> including an estimated one and a half million Jews killed by the <a href="/wiki/Einsatzgruppen" title="Einsatzgruppen">Einsatzgruppen</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[107]</a></sup> sometimes with the help of local collaborators. Of the estimated 8.6 million Soviet troop losses,<sup id="cite_ref-peremoga7_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peremoga7-112">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Krivosheev_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krivosheev-114">[110]</a></sup> 1.4 million were ethnic <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-peremoga7_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peremoga7-112">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Krivosheev_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krivosheev-114">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_C2"><a href="#endnote_C2">[c]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_Dnone"><a href="#endnote_Dnone">[d]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Eastern_Front)" class="mw-redirect" title="Victory Day (Eastern Front)">Victory Day</a> is celebrated as one of ten Ukrainian national holidays.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup> The losses of the Ukrainian people in the war amounted to 40â44% of the total losses of the USSR.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Post.E2.80.93World_War_II"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="PostâWorld_War_II">PostâWorld War II</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1953%E2%80%931964)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1953â1964)">History of the Soviet Union (1953â1964)</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1964%E2%80%931982)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1964â1982)">History of the Soviet Union (1964â1982)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1982%E2%80%931991)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1982â1991)">History of the Soviet Union (1982â1991)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/170px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="295" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/255px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/340px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg 2x" data-file-width="432" data-file-height="750"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Two future leaders of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> (left, pre-war <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">CPSU</a> chief in Ukraine) and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> (an engineer from <a href="/wiki/Kamianske" title="Kamianske">Kamianske</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>The republic was heavily damaged by the war, and it required significant efforts to recover. More than 700 cities and towns and 28,000 villages were destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> The situation was worsened by a <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a> in 1946â1947, which was caused by a drought and the wartime destruction of infrastructure. The death toll of this famine varies, with even the lowest estimate in the tens of thousands.<sup id="cite_ref-dt-kul-dem-los_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dt-kul-dem-los-110">[106]</a></sup> In 1945, the Ukrainian SSR became one of the founding members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> organization,<sup id="cite_ref-un_ukssr_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-un_ukssr-118">[114]</a></sup> part of a special agreement at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Post-war <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> occurred in the newly expanded Soviet Union. As of 1 January 1953, Ukrainians were second only to Russians among adult "<a href="/wiki/Forced_settlements_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Forced settlements in the Soviet Union">special deportees</a>", comprising 20% of the total.<sup id="cite_ref-Malynovska_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malynovska-120">[116]</a></sup> In addition, over 450,000 ethnic <a href="/wiki/History_of_Germans_in_Russia,_Ukraine_and_the_Soviet_Union" title="History of Germans in Russia, Ukraine and the Soviet Union">Germans</a> from Ukraine and more than 200,000 <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> were victims of <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">forced deportations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Malynovska_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malynovska-120">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the death of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Stalin</a> in 1953, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> became the new leader of the USSR. Having served as First Secretary of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine">Communist Party of Ukrainian SSR</a> in 1938â1949, Khrushchev was intimately familiar with the republic; after taking power union-wide, he began to emphasize "the friendship" between the Ukrainian and Russian nations. In 1954, the 300th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Pereyaslav" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Pereyaslav">Treaty of Pereyaslav</a> was widely celebrated. <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Oblast" title="Crimean Oblast">Crimea</a> was <a href="/wiki/1954_transfer_of_Crimea" title="1954 transfer of Crimea">transferred</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian SFSR">Russian SFSR</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1950, the republic had fully surpassed pre-war levels of industry and production.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> Soviet Ukraine soon became a European leader in industrial production<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup> and an important centre of the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">arms industry</a> and high-tech research. Such an important role resulted in a major influence of the local elite. Many members of the Soviet leadership came from Ukraine, most notably <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a>. He later ousted Khrushchev and became the Soviet leader from 1964 to 1982.
</p><p>On 26 April 1986, a reactor in the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant">Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant</a> exploded, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a>, the worst <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a> accident in history.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup> At the time of the accident, 7 million people lived in the contaminated territories, including 2.2 million in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Chernobyl.info_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chernobyl.info-125">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the accident, the new city of <a href="/wiki/Slavutych" title="Slavutych">Slavutych</a> was built outside the exclusion zone to house and support the employees of the plant, which was decommissioned in 2000. A report prepared by the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> attributed 56 direct deaths to the accident and estimated that there may have been 4,000 extra cancer deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-iaea_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaea-126">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">Independence</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Modern_history_of_Ukraine" title="Modern history of Ukraine">Modern history of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>On 21 January 1990, over 300,000 Ukrainians<sup id="cite_ref-subtelny-576_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-subtelny-576-127">[123]</a></sup> organised a human chain for Ukrainian independence between <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Act_Zluky" class="mw-redirect" title="Act Zluky">memory of the 1919 unification</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/West_Ukrainian_National_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="West Ukrainian National Republic">West Ukrainian National Republic</a>. Citizens came out to the streets and highways, forming live chains by holding hands in support of unity.
