</p><p>On 16 July 1990, the new parliament adopted the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_Ukraine" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine">Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[124]</a></sup> This established the principles of the self-determination, democracy, independence, and the priority of Ukrainian law over Soviet law. A month earlier, a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">similar declaration</a> was adopted by the parliament of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian SFSR">Russian SFSR</a>. This started a period of confrontation with the central Soviet authorities. On 2â17 October 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Revolution_on_Granite" title="Revolution on Granite">Revolution on Granite</a> took place in Ukraine, the main purpose of the action being to prevent the signing of a new union treaty of the USSR. The demands of the students were satisfied by signing a resolution of the Verkhovna Rada, which guaranteed their implementation.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>
In August 1991, a faction among the Communist leaders of the Soviet Union <a href="/wiki/Soviet_coup_attempt_of_1991" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet coup attempt of 1991">attempted a coup</a> to remove <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> and to restore the Communist party's power. After it failed, the Ukrainian parliament adopted the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Act of Independence of Ukraine">Act of Independence</a> on 24 August 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kravchuk" title="Leonid Kravchuk">Leonid Kravchuk</a> and President of the Russian Federation <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> signed the <a href="/wiki/Belavezha_Accords" class="mw-redirect" title="Belavezha Accords">Belavezha Accords</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolving the Soviet Union</a>, on 8 December 1991.</div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/1991_Ukrainian_independence_referendum" title="1991 Ukrainian independence referendum">referendum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1991_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="1991 Ukrainian presidential election">first presidential elections</a> took place on 1 December 1991. More than 92%<sup id="cite_ref-Nohlen_StÃ¶ver_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nohlen_StÃ¶ver-131">[127]</a></sup> of the electorate expressed their support for the Act of Independence, and they elected the chairman of the parliament, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kravchuk" title="Leonid Kravchuk">Leonid Kravchuk</a>, as the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">president of Ukraine</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/Belavezha_Accords" class="mw-redirect" title="Belavezha Accords">meeting in Brest</a>, Belarus on 8 December, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Alma_Ata" class="mw-redirect" title="Alma Ata">Alma Ata</a> meeting on 21 December, the leaders of Belarus, Russia and Ukraine formally dissolved the Soviet Union and formed the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (CIS).<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[128]</a></sup> On 26 December 1991 the Council of Republics of the USSR Supreme Council adopted the declaration "In regards to creation of the Commonwealth of Independent States" which de jure dissolved the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_flag" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet flag">Soviet flag</a> was lowered over <a href="/wiki/The_Kremlin" class="mw-redirect" title="The Kremlin">the Kremlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[129]</a></sup> The Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine did not ratify the accession, so Ukraine has never been a member of the CIS.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-134">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine was initially viewed as having favourable economic conditions in comparison to the other regions of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[131]</a></sup> However, the country experienced deeper economic slowdown than some of the other <a href="/wiki/Former_Soviet_Republics" class="mw-redirect" title="Former Soviet Republics">former Soviet Republics</a>. During the recession, between 1991 and 1999, Ukraine lost 60% of its GDP<sup id="cite_ref-IMF_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF-136">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[133]</a></sup> and suffered five-digit inflation rates.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup> Dissatisfied with the economic conditions, as well as the amounts of crime and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Ukraine" title="Corruption in Ukraine">corruption in Ukraine</a>, Ukrainians protested and organized strikes.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ukrainian economy stabilized by the end of the 1990s. A new currency, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_hryvnia" title="Ukrainian hryvnia">hryvnia</a>, was introduced in 1996. After 2000, the country enjoyed steady <a href="/wiki/Real_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Real GDP">real economic growth</a> averaging about seven percent annually.<sup id="cite_ref-Macroindicators_NBU_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Macroindicators_NBU-140">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[137]</a></sup> A new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a>, under the second President <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kuchma" title="Leonid Kuchma">Leonid Kuchma</a> in 1996, turned Ukraine into a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential republic">semi-presidential republic</a> and established a stable political system. Kuchma was, however, criticised by opponents for corruption, <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">electoral fraud</a>, discouraging free speech and concentrating too much power in his office.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[138]</a></sup> Ukraine also pursued full nuclear disarmament, giving up the third largest nuclear weapons stockpile in the world and dismantling or removing all strategic bombers on its territory in exchange for various assurances (main article: <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Ukraine" title="Nuclear weapons and Ukraine">Nuclear weapons and Ukraine</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Orange_Revolution">Orange Revolution</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/220px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/330px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/440px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="450"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Protesters at <a href="/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti" title="Maidan Nezalezhnosti">Independence Square</a> on the first day of the <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2004, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, then prime minister, was declared the winner of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2004 Ukrainian presidential election">presidential elections</a>, which the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a> later ruled had been largely rigged.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[140]</a></sup> The results caused a public outcry in support of the opposition candidate, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yushchenko" title="Viktor Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a>, who challenged the outcome. During the tumultuous months of the revolution, candidate Yushchenko <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yushchenko#TCDD_poisoning" title="Viktor Yushchenko">suddenly became gravely ill</a>, and was soon found by multiple independent physician groups to have been poisoned by <a href="/wiki/2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin" title="2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin">TCDD dioxin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CBS:_Yushchenko:_Live_And_Carry_On_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS:_Yushchenko:_Live_And_Carry_On-145">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_j_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_j-146">[142]</a></sup> Yushchenko strongly suspected Russian involvement in his poisoning.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009c_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009c-147">[143]</a></sup> All of this eventually resulted in the peaceful <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>, which brought Yushchenko and <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> to power, while casting Yanukovych in opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yanukovych returned to power in 2006 as prime minister in the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_of_National_Unity" class="mw-redirect" title="Alliance of National Unity">Alliance of National Unity</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[145]</a></sup> until <a href="/wiki/2007_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2007 Ukrainian parliamentary election">snap elections in September 2007</a> made Tymoshenko prime minister again.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup> Amid the <a href="/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Ukrainian_financial_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2008â09 Ukrainian financial crisis">2008â09 Ukrainian financial crisis</a> the Ukrainian economy shrank by 15%.<sup id="cite_ref-FT_2013_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT_2013-151">[147]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_gas_disputes" title="RussiaâUkraine gas disputes">Disputes with Russia</a> briefly stopped all gas supplies to Ukraine in 2006 and again in 2009, leading to gas shortages in other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup> Yanukovych was <a href="/wiki/2010_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2010 Ukrainian presidential election">elected President in 2010</a> with 48% of the vote.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Euromaidan_and_the_Revolution_of_Dignity">Euromaidan and the Revolution of Dignity</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Euromaidan" title="Timeline of the Euromaidan">Timeline of the Euromaidan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Euromaidan_01.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/220px-Euromaidan_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/330px-Euromaidan_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/440px-Euromaidan_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3230" data-file-height="2154"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Euromaidan_01.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pro-EU demonstration in Kyiv, 27 November 2013, during the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">ÐÐ²ÑÐ¾Ð¼Ð°Ð¹Ð´Ð°Ð½</span>, literally "Eurosquare") protests started in November 2013 after the president, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, began moving away from an association agreement that had been in the works with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and instead chose to establish closer ties with the Russian Federation.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc20131217_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc20131217-155">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[153]</a></sup> Some Ukrainians took to the streets to show their support for closer ties with Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Meanwhile, in the predominantly Russian-speaking east, a large portion of the population opposed the Euromaidan protests, instead supporting the Yanukovych government.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup> Over time, <i>Euromaidan</i> came to describe a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine,<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup> the scope of which evolved to include calls for the resignation of President Yanukovych and <a href="/wiki/Second_Azarov_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Azarov Government">his government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters20131212_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters20131212-161">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>Violence escalated after 16 January 2014 when the government accepted new <a href="/wiki/Anti-protest_laws_in_Ukraine" title="Anti-protest laws in Ukraine">Anti-Protest Laws</a>. Violent anti-government demonstrators occupied buildings in the centre of Kyiv, including the Justice Ministry building, and riots from 18 to 20 February left 98 dead, with approximately fifteen thousand injured and 100 missing.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> On 21 February, President Yanukovych signed a compromise deal with opposition leaders that promised constitutional changes to restore certain powers to Parliament and called for early elections to be held by December.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, Members of Parliament voted on 22 February to remove the president and set <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2014 Ukrainian presidential election">an election</a> for 25 May to select his replacement, a move described by Russia and US academic <a href="/wiki/John_Mearsheimer" title="John Mearsheimer">John Mearsheimer</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'Ã©tat">coup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup> The ousting<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup> of Yanukovych prompted <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> to begin preparations to annex Crimea on 23 February 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a>, running on a pro-European Union platform, won with over fifty percent of the vote, therefore not requiring a run-off election.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-176">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-177">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RTVi_2014_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTVi_2014-178">[174]</a></sup> Upon his election, Poroshenko announced that his immediate priorities would be to take action on the civil unrest in Eastern Ukraine and mend ties with the Russian Federation.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-176">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-177">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RTVi_2014_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTVi_2014-178">[174]</a></sup> In October 2014 <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election">Parliament elections</a>, the party <a href="/wiki/European_Solidarity#Petro_Poroshenko_Bloc_(2014â2019)" title="European Solidarity">Petro Poroshenko Bloc</a> won 132 of the 423 contested seats.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2014_Russian_armed_interventions_and_invasion">2014 Russian armed interventions and invasion</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For broader coverage of this topic, see <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations#Annexation_of_Crimea_and_war_in_eastern_Ukraine" title="RussiaâUkraine relations">RussiaâUkraine relations Â§ Annexation of Crimea and war in eastern Ukraine</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/220px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="239" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/330px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/440px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="4126" data-file-height="4480"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, which Russia annexed in 2014, is shown in pink. Pink in the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> area represents areas held by the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">DPR</a>/<a href="/wiki/Lugansk_People%27s_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Lugansk People's Republic">LPR</a> separatists in September 2014 (cities in red).</div></div></div>
<p>Using the Russian naval base at <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> as cover, Putin directed Russian troops and intelligence agents to disarm Ukrainian forces and take control of <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup> After the troops entered Crimea,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup> a controversial <a href="/wiki/2014_Crimean_referendum" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Crimean referendum">referendum</a> was held on 16 March 2014 and the official result was that 97 percent wished to join with Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 18 March 2014, Russia and the self-proclaimed Republic of Crimea signed a <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation#Accession_treaty_and_aftermath" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">treaty of accession of the Republic of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> in the Russian Federation. The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">UN General Assembly</a> immediately responded by passing <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">resolution 68/262</a> declaring that the referendum was invalid and supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine; only Russia voted against the resolution. However, it was not enforceable.<sup id="cite_ref-vote_isolates_russia_2014_03_27_nytimes_com_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vote_isolates_russia_2014_03_27_nytimes_com-186">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-unga_resolution_2014_03_27_cnn_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unga_resolution_2014_03_27_cnn-187">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ukraines_best_pitch_2014_09_23_nytimes_com_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ukraines_best_pitch_2014_09_23_nytimes_com-188">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-explainer_2022_01_31_usnews_com_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-explainer_2022_01_31_usnews_com-189">[185]</a></sup> Attempts to pass enforceable resolutions in the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">U.N. Security Council</a> were blocked by Russian <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">vetoes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ukraines_best_pitch_2014_09_23_nytimes_com_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ukraines_best_pitch_2014_09_23_nytimes_com-188">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-explainer_2022_01_31_usnews_com_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-explainer_2022_01_31_usnews_com-189">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-russia_vetoes_2014_03_16_nytimes_com_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-russia_vetoes_2014_03_16_nytimes_com-190">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Separately, in the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk" title="Luhansk">Luhansk</a> regions, armed men declaring themselves as local militia and supported by pro-Russian protesters<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup> seized government buildings, police and special<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="maybe delete "special" (March 2022)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> police stations in several cities and held unrecognised <a href="/wiki/2014_Donbas_status_referendums" title="2014 Donbas status referendums">status referendums</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> The insurgency was led by Russian emissaries <a href="/wiki/Igor_Girkin" title="Igor Girkin">Igor Girkin</a><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Borodai" title="Alexander Borodai">Alexander Borodai</a><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> as well as militants from Russia, such as <a href="/wiki/Arseny_Pavlov" class="mw-redirect" title="Arseny Pavlov">Arseny Pavlov</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> They proclaimed the self styled <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">Donetsk People's Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">Luhansk People's Republic</a> which have controlled about <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">1</span>â<span class="den">3</span></span> of the oblasts since then.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>Talks in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a> between the EU, Russia, Ukraine, and the United States yielded a Joint Diplomatic Statement referred to as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_Geneva_Pact&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="2014 Geneva Pact (page does not exist)">2014 Geneva Pact</a><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> in which the parties requested that all unlawful militias lay down their arms and vacate seized government buildings, and also establish a political dialogue that could lead to more autonomy for Ukraine's regions. When <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> won the presidential election held on 25 May 2014, he vowed to continue the military operations by the Ukrainian government forces to end the armed insurgency.<sup id="cite_ref-G26514P_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-G26514P-198">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2014, a bilateral commission of leading scholars from the United States and Russia issued the Boisto Agenda outlining a 24-step plan to resolve the crisis in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Uri_Friedman_2014_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uri_Friedman_2014-199">[195]</a></sup> The Boisto Agenda was organized into five imperative categories for addressing the crisis requiring stabilization identified as: (1) Elements of an Enduring, Verifiable Ceasefire; (2) Economic Relations; (3) Social and Cultural Issues; (4) Crimea; and, (5) International Status of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Uri_Friedman_2014_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uri_Friedman_2014-199">[195]</a></sup> In late 2014, Ukraine ratified the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement">UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement</a>, which Poroshenko described as Ukraine's "first but most decisive step" towards EU membership.<sup id="cite_ref-DW_16.09.2014_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DW_16.09.2014-200">[196]</a></sup> Poroshenko also set 2020 as the target for <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="UkraineâEuropean Union relations">EU membership application</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters_Sep_25,_2014_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_Sep_25,_2014-201">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_(16705750566).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/220px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/330px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/440px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2002"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_(16705750566).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/OSCE" class="mw-redirect" title="OSCE">OSCE</a> SMM monitoring the movement of heavy weaponry in eastern Ukraine, 4 March 2015</div></div></div>
<p>In February 2015, after a summit hosted in <a href="/wiki/Minsk,_Belarus" class="mw-redirect" title="Minsk, Belarus">Minsk, Belarus</a>, Poroshenko negotiated a ceasefire with the separatist troops. The resulting agreements, known as the <a href="/wiki/Minsk_Protocol" class="mw-redirect" title="Minsk Protocol">Minsk Protocol</a>, included conditions such as the withdrawal of heavy weaponry from the front line and decentralisation of rebel regions by the end of 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-WilkenfeldBeardsleyQuinn2019_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WilkenfeldBeardsleyQuinn2019-202">[198]</a></sup> They also included conditions such as Ukrainian control of the border with Russia in 2015 and the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Ukrainian territory. The ceasefire began on 15 February 2015. Participants in this ceasefire also agreed to attend regular meetings to ensure that the agreement was respected.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_Feb_12,_2015_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian_Feb_12,_2015-203">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 January 2016, Ukraine joined the <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> with the European Union,<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine-21">[17]</a></sup> which aims to modernize and develop Ukraine's economy, governance and rule of law to EU standards and gradually increase integration with the EU <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">Internal market</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DCFTA_Ukr_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DCFTA_Ukr-204">[200]</a></sup> In 2017 the European Union approved visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens: entitling Ukrainians to travel to the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Schengen area">Schengen area</a> for tourism, family visits and business reasons, with the only document required being a valid biometric passport.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[201]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prelude_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Prelude to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Prelude to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>In spring 2021, Russia began building up troop strengths along its border with Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[203]</a></sup> On 22 February 2022, Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> ordered military forces to enter the breakaway Ukrainian republics of <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">Donetsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">Luhansk</a>, calling the act a "peacekeeping mission". Putin also officially recognized Donetsk and Luhansk as sovereign states, fully independent from the Ukrainian government.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early hours of 24 February 2022, Putin <a href="/wiki/On_conducting_a_special_military_operation" title="On conducting a special military operation">announced</a> a "special military operation" to "<a href="/wiki/Demilitarise" class="mw-redirect" title="Demilitarise">demilitarise</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denazification#Misuse_of_term" title="Denazification">denazify</a>" Ukraine, and launched a large-scale invasion of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup> Later in the day, the Ukrainian government announced that Russia had taken control of <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl" title="Chernobyl">Chernobyl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[207]</a></sup> On 28 February 2022, Ukraine asked for immediate admission to the European Union in response to the invasion.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>One month after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, it appeared that early Russian predictions for a quick victory in Ukraine were based on faulty Russian intelligence.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup> Russia had not yet achieved its two primary initial objectives, the capture of Ukraine's two largest cities, Kyiv and Kharkiv, with Ukrainian counter-offensives pushing back Russian front lines around Kyiv.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[210]</a></sup> Several newspapers reported a woefully under-trained Russian army and of a lack of adequate Russian equipment, food, and weaponry.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to one Russian news station, over 9,861 Russian troops and at least 5 Russian generals have been killed to date and another 30,000 have been injured, captured, or are missing in action. The mounting bad news for the Russian military is believed to have begun to have a negative impact on the morale of the Russian troops.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup> Some military analysts are now beginning to refer to the progress of the war as devolving into a "stalemate situation".<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ukraine" title="Geography of Ukraine">Geography of Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pontic_Caspian_climate.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pontic_Caspian_climate.png/220px-Pontic_Caspian_climate.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pontic_Caspian_climate.png/330px-Pontic_Caspian_climate.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pontic_Caspian_climate.png/440px-Pontic_Caspian_climate.png 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="436"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pontic_Caspian_climate.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Simplified depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Biome" title="Biome">biomes</a> lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropics</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">second-largest European country</a>, after Russia. Lying between latitudes <a href="/wiki/44th_parallel_north" title="44th parallel north">44Â°</a> and <a href="/wiki/53rd_parallel_north" title="53rd parallel north">53Â° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/22nd_meridian_east" title="22nd meridian east">22Â°</a> and <a href="/wiki/41st_meridian_east" title="41st meridian east">41Â° E</a>., it is mostly in the <a href="/wiki/East_European_Plain" title="East European Plain">East European Plain</a>. Ukraine covers an area of 603,628 square kilometres (233,062 sq mi), with a coastline of 2,782 kilometres (1,729 mi).<sup id="cite_ref-cia_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-49">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile plains (or <a href="/wiki/Steppes" class="mw-redirect" title="Steppes">steppes</a>) and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper</a> (<span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn">Dnipro</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Seversky_Donets" class="mw-redirect" title="Seversky Donets">Seversky Donets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dniester" title="Dniester">Dniester</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Bug" title="Southern Bug">Southern Bug</a> as they flow south into the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and the smaller <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a>. To the southwest, the <a href="/wiki/Danube_Delta" title="Danube Delta">delta</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> forms the border with Romania. Ukraine's various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands. The country's only mountains are the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the west, of which the highest is <a href="/wiki/Hoverla" title="Hoverla">Hoverla</a> at 2,061 metres (6,762 ft), and the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Mountains" title="Crimean Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a>, in the extreme south along the coast.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the <a href="/wiki/Volhynian-Podolian_Upland" title="Volhynian-Podolian Upland">Volyn-Podillia Upland</a> (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Russian_Upland" title="Central Russian Upland">Central Russian Upland</a> over which runs the border with the Russian Federation. Near the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a> can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The <a href="/wiki/Snow_melt" class="mw-redirect" title="Snow melt">snow melt</a> from the mountains feeds the rivers and their <a href="/wiki/Waterfalls_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterfalls of Ukraine">waterfalls</a>.
</p><p>Significant natural resources in Ukraine include lithium,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup> natural gas,<sup id="cite_ref-:0_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-223">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kaolin" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaolin">kaolin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-:0_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-223">[219]</a></sup> timber<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup> and an abundance of arable land.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[221]</a></sup> Ukraine has many environmental issues.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> Some regions lack adequate supplies of potable water.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup> Air and water pollution affects the country, as well as deforestation, and radiation contamination in the northeast stemming from the 1986 accident at the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl" title="Chernobyl">Chernobyl</a> Nuclear Power Plant.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg/260px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg/390px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg/520px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1816" data-file-height="850"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_UKR_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine has a mostly <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate climate</a>, except for the southern coast of Crimea which has a <a href="/wiki/Subtropical_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Subtropical climate">subtropical climate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-faoclimate_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faoclimate-230">[226]</a></sup> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air from the Atlantic Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-231">[227]</a></sup> Average annual temperatures range from 5.5â7 Â°C (41.9â44.6 Â°F) in the north, to 11â13 Â°C (51.8â55.4 Â°F) in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-231">[227]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_231-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-231">[227]</a></sup> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains, receives around 120 centimetres (47.2 in) of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around 40 centimetres (15.7 in).<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_231-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-231">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup> The negative impacts of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a> climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> has stated that Ukraine is highly vulnerable to climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Ukraine" title="Wildlife of Ukraine">Wildlife of Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Klavdievo_forest.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Klavdievo_forest.JPG/220px-Klavdievo_forest.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Klavdievo_forest.JPG/330px-Klavdievo_forest.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Klavdievo_forest.JPG/440px-Klavdievo_forest.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1777"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Klavdievo_forest.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pine forest near Klavdievo, Borodianka Raion, <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_Oblast" title="Kyiv Oblast">Kyiv Oblast</a>,</div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine contains six terrestrial <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Central_European_mixed_forests" title="Central European mixed forests">Central European mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Submediterranean_forest_complex" title="Crimean Submediterranean forest complex">Crimean Submediterranean forest complex</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_European_forest_steppe" title="East European forest steppe">East European forest steppe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_mixed_forests" title="Pannonian mixed forests">Pannonian mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_montane_conifer_forests" title="Carpathian montane conifer forests">Carpathian montane conifer forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_steppe" class="mw-redirect" title="Pontic steppe">Pontic steppe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-235">[231]</a></sup> There is somewhat more <a href="/wiki/Conifer" title="Conifer">coniferous</a> than <a href="/wiki/Deciduous" title="Deciduous">deciduous</a> forest.<sup id="cite_ref-ShvidenkoBukshaKrakovska2017_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ShvidenkoBukshaKrakovska2017-236">[232]</a></sup> The most densely forested area is <a href="/wiki/Polisia" class="mw-redirect" title="Polisia">Polisia</a> in the northwest; with pine, oak, and birch.<sup id="cite_ref-ShvidenkoBukshaKrakovska2017_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ShvidenkoBukshaKrakovska2017-236">[232]</a></sup> There are 45,000 species of animal,<sup id="cite_ref-Conference2001_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Conference2001-237">[233]</a></sup> with approximately 385 endangered species listed in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Data_Book_of_Ukraine" title="Red Data Book of Ukraine">Red Data Book of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-State_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State-238">[234]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_site" title="Ramsar site">Internationally important wetlands</a> cover over 7,000 square kilometres (2,700 sq mi), with the <a href="/wiki/Danube_Delta" title="Danube Delta">Danube Delta</a> being important for conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-wetland_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wetland-239">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ramsar_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ramsar-240">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Ukraine" title="Politics of Ukraine">Politics of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ukraine" title="Government of Ukraine">Government of Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine" title="Elections in Ukraine">Elections in Ukraine</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/2014_Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine">2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas" title="War in Donbas">War in Donbas</a></div>
<p>Ukraine is a republic under a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a> with separate <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive branch">executive</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial branch">judicial branches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Choudhry_2018_p16._241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Choudhry_2018_p16.-241">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitution_of_Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg/260px-Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg/390px-Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg/520px-Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1052" data-file-height="744"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Chart_Constitution_of_Ukraine_EN.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chart for the political system of Ukraine</div></div></div>
<p>The Constitution of Ukraine was adopted and ratified at the 5th session of the <i><a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada" title="Verkhovna Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a></i>, the parliament of Ukraine, on 28 June 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-UNIANCD28616_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNIANCD28616-242">[238]</a></sup> The constitution was passed with 315 ayes out of 450 votes possible (300 ayes minimum).<sup id="cite_ref-UNIANCD28616_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNIANCD28616-242">[238]</a></sup> All other laws and other normative<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (March 2022)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> legal acts of Ukraine must conform to the constitution. The right to amend the constitution through a special legislative procedure is vested exclusively in the parliament. The only body that may interpret the constitution and determine whether legislation conforms to it is the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Constitutional Court of Ukraine">Constitutional Court of Ukraine</a>. Since 1996, the <a href="/wiki/Public_holiday" title="Public holiday">public holiday</a> <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Day_(Ukraine)" title="Constitution Day (Ukraine)">Constitution Day</a> is celebrated on 28 June.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UW29121996_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UW29121996-244">[240]</a></sup> On 7 February 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada" title="Verkhovna Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a> voted to amend the constitution to state Ukraine's strategic objectives as joining the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="President.2C_parliament_and_government"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="President,_parliament_and_government">President, parliament and government</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align:center;">

<tbody><tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/File:Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Volodymyr Zelensky Official portrait.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/141px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="141" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/212px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/282px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3488" data-file-height="4724"></a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="ÐÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð¨Ð¼Ð¸Ð³Ð°Ð»Ñ 2020 3 (cropped).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/143px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="143" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/215px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/286px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="602" data-file-height="803"></a>
</td></tr>
<tr class="nowrap">
<td><a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a><br><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">President</a></small>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Denys_Shmyhal" title="Denys Shmyhal">Denys Shmyhal</a><br><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ukraine" title="Prime Minister of Ukraine">Prime Minister</a></small>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">president</a> is elected by popular vote for a five-year term and is the formal <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[242]</a></sup>
Ukraine's legislative branch includes the 450-seat <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament, the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada" title="Verkhovna Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup> The parliament is primarily responsible for the formation of the executive branch and the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Ministers_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine">Cabinet of Ministers</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ukraine" title="Prime Minister of Ukraine">prime minister</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup> The president retains the authority to nominate the ministers of foreign affairs and of defence for parliamentary approval, as well as the power to appoint the <a href="/wiki/Prosecutor_General_of_Ukraine" title="Prosecutor General of Ukraine">prosecutor general</a> and the head of the <a href="/wiki/Security_Service_of_Ukraine" title="Security Service of Ukraine">Security Service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>Laws, acts of the parliament and the cabinet, presidential decrees, and acts of the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada_of_Crimea" title="Verkhovna Rada of Crimea">Crimean parliament</a> may be abrogated by the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Constitutional Court of Ukraine">Constitutional Court</a>, should they be found to violate the constitution. Other normative acts are subject to judicial review. The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court</a> is the main body in the system of courts of general jurisdiction.
Local self-government is officially guaranteed. Local councils and city mayors are popularly elected and exercise control over local budgets. The heads of regional and district administrations are appointed by the president in accordance with the proposals of the prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-House2004_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-House2004-250">[246]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Courts_and_law_enforcement">Courts and law enforcement</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial system of Ukraine">Judicial system of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Law enforcement in Ukraine">Law enforcement in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street,_Pechersk_Raion,_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/220px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/330px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/440px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3900" data-file-height="2338"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street,_Pechersk_Raion,_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Klov_Palace" title="Klov Palace">Klovsky Palace</a>, home to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Ukraine" title="Martial law in Ukraine">Martial law in Ukraine</a> was declared immediately upon the beginning of the Russian invasion in February 2022,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> and continues until at least late April 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>The courts enjoy legal, financial and constitutional freedom guaranteed by Ukrainian law since 2002. Judges are largely well protected from dismissal (except in the instance of gross misconduct). Court justices are appointed by presidential decree for an initial period of five years, after which Ukraine's Supreme Council confirms their positions for life. Although there are still problems, the system is considered to have been much improved since Ukraine's independence in 1991. The Supreme Court is regarded as an independent and impartial body, and has on several occasions ruled against the Ukrainian government. The <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">World Justice Project</a> ranks Ukraine 66 out of 99 countries surveyed in its annual Rule of Law Index.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Prosecutor" title="Prosecutor">Prosecutors</a> in Ukraine have greater powers than in most European countries, and according to the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission_for_Democracy_through_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="European Commission for Democracy through Law">European Commission for Democracy through Law</a> 'the role and functions of the Prosecutor's Office is not in accordance with <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> standards".<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup> The criminal judicial system maintains an average <a href="/wiki/Conviction_rate" title="Conviction rate">conviction rate</a> of over 99%,<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup> equal to the conviction rate of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, with<sup id="cite_ref-Moskal_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moskal-256">[252]</a></sup> suspects often being incarcerated for long periods before trial.<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-257">[253]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8,_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG/220px-%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG/330px-%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG/440px-%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%BA_%D1%83%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8,_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ukraine" title="Government of Ukraine">Cabinet of Ministers</a> building</div></div></div>
<p>On 24 March 2010, President Yanukovych formed an expert group to make recommendations on how to "clean up the current mess and adopt a law on court organization".<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-257">[253]</a></sup> One day later, he stated "We can no longer disgrace our country with such a court system."<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_257-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-257">[253]</a></sup> The criminal judicial system and the prison system of Ukraine remain quite punitive.<sup id="cite_ref-United_States_Department_of_State_2021_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_States_Department_of_State_2021-258">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1 January 2010 it has been permissible to hold court proceedings in Russian by mutual consent of the parties. Citizens unable to speak <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> or Russian may use their native language or the services of a translator.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> Previously all court proceedings had to be held in Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-United_States_Department_of_State_2021_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_States_Department_of_State_2021-258">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>Law enforcement agencies in Ukraine are organised under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Internal_Affairs_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine">Ministry of Internal Affairs</a>. They consist primarily of the <a href="/wiki/National_Police_of_Ukraine" title="National Police of Ukraine">national police force</a> and various specialised units and agencies such as the <a href="/wiki/State_Border_Guard_Service_of_Ukraine" title="State Border Guard Service of Ukraine">State Border Guard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Sea_Guard" title="Ukrainian Sea Guard">Coast Guard</a> services. Law enforcement agencies, particularly the police, faced criticism for their heavy handling of the 2004 <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>. Many thousands of police officers were stationed throughout the capital, primarily to dissuade protesters from challenging the state's authority but also to provide a quick reaction force in case of need; most officers were armed.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTSBU_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTSBU-261">[257]</a></sup> 
</p><p>The Ministry of Internal Affairs is also responsible for the maintenance of the <a href="/wiki/Security_Service_of_Ukraine" title="Security Service of Ukraine">State Security Service</a>; Ukraine's domestic intelligence agency, which has on occasion been accused of acting like a <a href="/wiki/Secret_police" title="Secret police">secret police</a> force serving to protect the country's political elite from media criticism. On the other hand, however, it is widely accepted that members of the service provided vital information about government plans to the leaders of the Orange Revolution to prevent the collapse of the movement.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Ukraine" title="Foreign relations of Ukraine">Foreign relations of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_membership_of_Ukraine" title="International membership of Ukraine">International membership of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="UkraineâEuropean Union relations">UkraineâEuropean Union relations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_and_the_World_Bank" title="Ukraine and the World Bank">Ukraine and the World Bank</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Batumi_International_Conference,_on_19_July_2021_03_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Batumi International Conference, on 19 July 2021 03 (cropped).jpg"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Batumi_International_Conference%2C_on_19_July_2021_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1931" data-file-height="1287"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Batumi_International_Conference,_on_19_July_2021_03_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_Georgia" title="President of Georgia">President of Georgia</a> <a href="/wiki/Salome_Zourabichvili" title="Salome Zourabichvili">Salome Zurabishvili</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_Moldova" title="President of Moldova">President of Moldova</a> <a href="/wiki/Maia_Sandu" title="Maia Sandu">Maia Sandu</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">Ukrainian President</a> <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> and <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">European Council President</a> <a href="/wiki/Charles_Michel" title="Charles Michel">Charles Michel</a> during the 2021 International Conference in <a href="/wiki/Batumi" title="Batumi">Batumi</a>. In 2014, the EU signed association agreements with all three countries.</div></div></div>
<p>From 1999 to 2001, Ukraine served as a non-permanent member of the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a>. Historically, Soviet Ukraine joined the United Nations in 1945 as one of the original members following a Western compromise with the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-U.S._Department_of_State,_Bureau_of_Public_Affairs,_Office_of_Public_Communication,_Editorial_Division.2000_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-U.S._Department_of_State,_Bureau_of_Public_Affairs,_Office_of_Public_Communication,_Editorial_Division.2000-262">[258]</a></sup> Ukraine has consistently supported peaceful, negotiated settlements to disputes. It has participated in the quadripartite talks on the conflict in Moldova and promoted a peaceful resolution to the conflict in the post-Soviet state of Georgia. Ukraine also has made contributions to UN <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> operations since 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-NATO_Information_Service._263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NATO_Information_Service.-263">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine considers Euro-Atlantic integration its primary foreign policy objective,<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-264">[260]</a></sup> but in practice it has always balanced its relationship with the European Union and the United States with strong ties to Russia. The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Partnership_and_Cooperation_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Partnership and Cooperation Agreement">Partnership and Cooperation Agreement</a> (PCA) with Ukraine went into force in 1998. The European Union (EU) has encouraged Ukraine to implement the PCA fully before discussions begin on an association agreement, issued at the EU Summit in December 1999 in <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>, recognizes Ukraine's long-term aspirations but does not discuss association.<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-264">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1992, Ukraine joined the then-Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (now the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe</a> (OSCE)), and also became a member of the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Cooperation_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Cooperation Council">North Atlantic Cooperation Council</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="UkraineâNATO relations">UkraineâNATO relations</a> are close and the country has declared interest in eventual membership.<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_264-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-264">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine is the most active member of the <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> (PfP). All major political parties in Ukraine support full eventual integration into the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[261]</a></sup> The Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union was signed in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Ukraine long had close ties with all its neighbours, but <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="RussiaâUkraine relations">RussiaâUkraine relations</a> rapidly deteriorated in 2014 due to the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexation of Crimea</a>, energy dependence and payment disputes. </p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/220px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/330px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/440px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="520"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In January 2016, Ukraine joined the <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> (green) with the EU (blue), established by the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement">UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement</a>, opening its path towards <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>.</div></div></div><p>The <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> (DCFTA), which entered into force in January 2016 following the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement">UkraineâEuropean Union Association Agreement</a>, formally integrates Ukraine into the <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[264]</a></sup> Ukraine receives further support and assistance for its <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">EU-accession</a> aspirations from the International VisegrÃ¡d Fund of the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="VisegrÃ¡d Group">VisegrÃ¡d Group</a> that consists of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central European</a> <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">EU members</a> the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia.<sup id="cite_ref-269"
