class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, in <a href="/wiki/Lublin" title="Lublin">Lublin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, Poland and Ukraine created the <a href="/wiki/Lublin_Triangle" title="Lublin Triangle">Lublin Triangle</a> initiative, which aims to create further cooperation between the three historical countries of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a> and further Ukraine's integration and accession to the <a href="/wiki/EU" class="mw-redirect" title="EU">EU</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Association_Trio" title="Association Trio">Association Trio</a> was formed by signing a joint memorandum between the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Georgia" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Georgia">Foreign Ministers of Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_and_European_Integration_of_Moldova" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration of Moldova">Moldova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Ukraine)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Ukraine)">Ukraine</a>. The Association Trio is a tripartite format for enhanced cooperation, coordination, and dialogue between the three countries (that have signed the Association Agreement with the EU) with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> on issues of common interest related to <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>, enhancing cooperation within the framework of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Partnership" title="Eastern Partnership">Eastern Partnership</a>, and committing to the prospect of joining the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> As of 2021, Ukraine was preparing to formally apply for <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> membership in 2024, in order to join the European Union in the 2030s,<sup id="cite_ref-:1_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-272">[268]</a></sup> however, with the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy requested that the country be admitted to the EU immediately.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-273">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Armed_forces">Armed forces</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine" title="Armed Forces of Ukraine">Armed Forces of Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kissing_the_flag.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/220px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/330px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/440px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1090" data-file-height="810"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kissing_the_flag.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Henadii Lachkov, commander of the Ukrainian contingent in <a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq" title="Multi-National Force â Iraq">Multi-National Force â Iraq</a>, kisses his country's flag</div></div></div>
<p>After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine inherited a 780,000-man military force on its territory, equipped with the third-largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Ukraine" title="Nuclear weapons and Ukraine">nuclear weapons arsenal</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-milgov_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milgov-274">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> In 1992, Ukraine signed the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Protocol" title="Lisbon Protocol">Lisbon Protocol</a> in which the country agreed to give up all nuclear weapons to Russia for disposal and to join the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a> as a non-nuclear weapon state. By 1996 the country had become free of nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-milgov_274-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milgov-274">[270]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine took consistent steps toward reduction of conventional weapons. It signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_Conventional_Armed_Forces_in_Europe" title="Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe">Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe</a>, which called for reduction of tanks, artillery, and armoured vehicles (army forces were reduced to 300,000). The country plans to convert the current <a href="/wiki/Conscript" class="mw-redirect" title="Conscript">conscript</a>-based military into a professional <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">volunteer military</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wbook06_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbook06-276">[272]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="old (March 2022)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Ukraine's current military consist of 196,600 active personnel and around 900,000 reservists.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/220px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/330px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/440px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5320" data-file-height="3540"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Ukrainian frigate <a href="/wiki/Hetman_Sahaydachniy_(U130)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hetman Sahaydachniy (U130)"><i>Hetman Sahaydachniy</i> (U130)</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine played an increasing role in peacekeeping operations. In 2014, the Ukrainian frigate <i>Hetman Sagaidachniy</i> joined the European Union's counter piracy <a href="/wiki/Operation_Atalanta" title="Operation Atalanta">Operation Atalanta</a> and was part of the EU Naval Force off the coast of <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a> for two months.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[274]</a></sup> Ukrainian troops were deployed in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Ukrainian_Peace_Force_Battalion" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Ukrainian Peace Force Battalion">Ukrainian-Polish Battalion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>A Ukrainian unit was deployed in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, as part of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">UN Interim Force</a> enforcing the mandated ceasefire agreement. There was also a maintenance and training battalion deployed in <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a>. In 2003â05, a Ukrainian unit was deployed as part of the <a href="/wiki/Multinational_force_in_Iraq" class="mw-redirect" title="Multinational force in Iraq">multinational force in Iraq</a> under Polish command.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>Military units of other states participated in multinational military exercises with Ukrainian forces in Ukraine regularly, including <a href="/wiki/U.S._military" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. military">U.S. military</a> forces.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following independence, Ukraine declared itself a neutral state.<sup id="cite_ref-gska2.rada.gov.ua_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gska2.rada.gov.ua-20">[16]</a></sup> The country had a limited military partnership with Russian Federation and other CIS countries and has had a <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">partnership with NATO</a> since 1994. In the 2000s, the government was leaning towards NATO, and deeper cooperation with the alliance was set by the NATO-Ukraine Action Plan signed in 2002. It was later agreed that the question of joining NATO should be answered by a national referendum at some point in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-wbook06_276-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbook06-276">[272]</a></sup> Deposed <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_President" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian President">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> considered the current level of co-operation between <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="UkraineâNATO relations">Ukraine and NATO</a> sufficient, and was against Ukraine joining NATO. During the <a href="/wiki/2008_Bucharest_summit" title="2008 Bucharest summit">2008 Bucharest summit</a>, NATO declared that Ukraine would eventually become a member of NATO when it meets the criteria for accession.
</p><p>As part of modernization after the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a> in 2014, junior officers were allowed to take more initiative and a <a href="/wiki/Territorial_defence_battalions_(Ukraine)" title="Territorial defence battalions (Ukraine)">territorial defense force</a> of volunteers was established.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[278]</a></sup> Various defensive weapons including <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned combat aerial vehicle">drones</a> were supplied by many countries, but not fighter jets.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[279]</a></sup> During the first few weeks of the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion</a> the military found it difficult to defend against shelling, missiles and high level bombing; but light infantry used shoulder-mounted weapons effectively to destroy tanks, armoured vehicles and low-flying aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Ukraine" title="Administrative divisions of Ukraine">Administrative divisions of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_historical_regions" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian historical regions">Ukrainian historical regions</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Crimea_and_Sevastopol" class="mw-redirect" title="Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol">Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png/350px-Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png/525px-Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png/700px-Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png 2x" data-file-width="4844" data-file-height="3255"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Ukraine_with_Cities.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ukraine (2021) â major cities and adjacent countries</div></div></div>
<p>The system of Ukrainian subdivisions reflects the country's status as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> (as stated in the country's constitution) with unified legal and <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">administrative</a> regimes for each unit.
</p><p>Including Sevastopol and the Autonomous Republic of Crimea that were annexed by the Russian Federation in 2014, Ukraine consists of 27 regions: twenty-four <a href="/wiki/Oblast" title="Oblast">oblasts</a> (provinces), one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_republic" title="Autonomous republic">autonomous republic</a> (<a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Republic_of_Crimea" title="Autonomous Republic of Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>), and two cities of special statusâ<a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, the capital, and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>. The 24 oblasts and Crimea are subdivided into 136<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[281]</a></sup> <span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Raion" title="Raion">raions</a></i></span> (districts) and city municipalities of regional significance, or second-level administrative units.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Populated_places_in_Ukraine" title="Populated places in Ukraine">Populated places in Ukraine</a> are split into two categories: urban and rural. Urban populated places are split further into cities and <a href="/wiki/Urban-type_settlement" title="Urban-type settlement">urban-type settlements</a> (a Soviet administrative invention), while rural populated places consist of villages and settlements (a generally used term). All cities have a certain degree of self-rule depending on their significance such as national significance (as in the case of Kyiv and Sevastopol), regional significance (within each oblast or autonomous republic) or district significance (all the rest of cities). A city's significance depends on several factors such as its population, socio-economic and historical importance and infrastructure.
</p>

<p>In 2021 agriculture was the biggest sector of the economy and Ukraine was the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Grain_trade" title="Grain trade">wheat exporter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[282]</a></sup> However, Ukraine remains among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_in_Europe_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of sovereign states in Europe by GDP (nominal) per capita">poorest countries in Europe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-poor_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poor-23">[19]</a></sup> and in 2021 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Ukraine" title="Corruption in Ukraine">corruption in the country</a> was rated worst on the continent after <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[283]</a></sup> In 2021 Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> per capita by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> was just over $14,000.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[284]</a></sup> Despite supplying emergency financial support, the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a> expected the economy to shrink considerably in 2022 due to <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russia's invasion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, the average salary in Ukraine reached its highest level at almost <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_hryvnia" title="Ukrainian hryvnia">â´</a>14,300 (US$525) per month.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[286]</a></sup> About 1% of Ukrainians lived <a href="/wiki/Poverty_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Poverty by country">below the national poverty line</a> in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[287]</a></sup> Unemployment in Ukraine was 4.5% in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[288]</a></sup> In 2019 5â15% of the Ukrainian population were categorized as middle class.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[289]</a></sup> In 2020 Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">government debt</a> was roughly 50% of its nominal GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:4_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-295">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>
In 2021 mineral commodities and light industry were important sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_295-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-295">[291]</a></sup> Ukraine produces nearly all types of transportation vehicles and <a href="/wiki/State_Space_Agency_of_Ukraine" title="State Space Agency of Ukraine">spacecraft</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[294]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonov" title="Antonov">Antonov</a> airplanes and <a href="/wiki/KrAZ" title="KrAZ">KrAZ</a> trucks are exported to many countries. The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> is the country's main trade partner, and remittances from Ukrainians working abroad are important.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_295-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-295">[291]</a></sup> </p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg/330px-%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg/440px-%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3772" data-file-height="2514"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8F.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kamianets-Podilskyi_Castle" title="Kamianets-Podilskyi Castle">Kamianets-Podilskyi Castle</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a></div></div></div>
<p>Before the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian war</a> the number of <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Ukraine" title="Tourism in Ukraine">tourists visiting Ukraine</a> was eighth in Europe, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">rankings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[295]</a></sup> Ukraine has numerous tourist attractions: mountain ranges suitable for <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, hiking and fishing: the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coastline as a popular summer destination; <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a> of different <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a>; churches, <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">castle</a> ruins and other architectural and park landmarks; various <a href="/wiki/Outdoor_activity" class="mw-redirect" title="Outdoor activity">outdoor activity</a> points. <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odessa" title="Odessa">Odessa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kamyanets-Podilskyi" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamyanets-Podilskyi">Kamyanets-Podilskyi</a> were Ukraine's principal tourist centres each offering many historical landmarks as well as formidable <a href="/wiki/Hospitality" title="Hospitality">hospitality</a> infrastructure. Tourism used to be the mainstay of Crimea's economy, but there was a major fall in visitor numbers following the Russian annexation in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seven_Natural_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine</a> are the selection of the most important landmarks of Ukraine, chosen by the general public through an Internet-based vote.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<p>Ukraine is among the worldâs top agricultural producers and exporters and is often described as the âbread basket of Europeâ. During the 2020/21 international wheat marketing season (July-June), it ranked as the sixth largest wheat exporter, accounting for nine percent of world wheat trade.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-301">[297]</a></sup> The country is also a major global exporter of maize, barley and rapeseed. In 2020/21, it accounted for 12 percent of global trade in <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a> and for 14 percent of world <a href="/wiki/Rapeseed" title="Rapeseed">rapeseed</a> exports. Its trade share is even greater in the sunflower oil sector, with the country accounting for about 50 percent of world exports in 2020/2021.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-301">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations</a> (FAO), further to causing the loss of lives and increasing humanitarian needs, the likely disruptions caused by the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a> to Ukraineâs grain and oilseed sectors, combined with potential food and fertilizer export difficulties encountered by the Russian Federation as a result of economic sanctions, could jeopardize the food security of many countries, especially those that are highly dependent on Ukraine and the Russian Federation for their food and fertilizer imports.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[298]</a></sup> Several of these countries fall into the <a href="/wiki/Least_developed_countries" title="Least developed countries">Least Developed Country</a> (LDC) group, while many others belong to the group of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Low-Income_Food-Deficit_Countries&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Low-Income Food-Deficit Countries (page does not exist)">Low-Income Food-Deficit Countries</a> (LIFDCs).<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[300]</a></sup> For example <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a> sourced 47 percent of its wheat imports in 2021 from Ukraine. The other 53 percent all came from the Russian Federation. Overall, more than 30 nations depend on Ukraine and the Russian Federation for over 30 percent of their wheat import needs, with many of them located in North Africa, and in Western and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_301-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-301">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Ukraine" title="Transport in Ukraine">Transport in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="HRCS2 unit" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/330px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/440px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2232" data-file-height="1611"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/HRCS2_multiple_unit" class="mw-redirect" title="HRCS2 multiple unit">HRCS2 multiple unit</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Railways" title="Ukrainian Railways">Rail transport</a> is heavily utilised in Ukraine.</div></div></div>
<p>Many roads and bridges were destroyed, and international maritime travel was blocked by the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[301]</a></sup> Before that it was mainly through the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Odessa" title="Port of Odessa">Port of Odessa</a>, from where ferries sailed regularly to <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Varna,_Bulgaria" title="Varna, Bulgaria">Varna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>. The largest ferry company operating these routes was <a href="/wiki/UkrFerry" title="UkrFerry">Ukrferry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[302]</a></sup> There are over 1,600 km (1,000 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Navigability" title="Navigability">navigable</a> waterways on 7 rivers, mostly on the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pripyat_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Pripyat River">Pripyat</a>. All Ukraine's rivers freeze over in winter, limiting navigation.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Ukraine" title="Rail transport in Ukraine">Rail transport in Ukraine</a> connects all major urban areas, port facilities and <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">industrial centres</a> with neighbouring countries. The heaviest concentration of <a href="/wiki/Railway_track" title="Railway track">railway track</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[304]</a></sup> Although <a href="/wiki/Rail_freight_transport" title="Rail freight transport">rail freight transport</a> fell in the 1990s, Ukraine is still one of the <a href="/wiki/Rail_usage_statistics_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Rail usage statistics by country">world's highest rail users</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ukraine_International_Airlines" title="Ukraine International Airlines">Ukraine International Airlines</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Airline" title="Airline">airline</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[306]</a></sup> with its head office in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[307]</a></sup> and its main hub at Kyiv's <a href="/wiki/Boryspil_International_Airport" title="Boryspil International Airport">Boryspil International Airport</a>. It operated domestic and international passenger flights and cargo services to Europe, the Middle East, the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-273">[269]</a></sup> Canada,<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[308]</a></sup> and Asia.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Ukraine" title="Energy in Ukraine">Energy in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg/260px-Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg/390px-Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg/520px-Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="850" data-file-height="600"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Electricity production by source, Ukraine</div></div></div>
<p>Energy in Ukraine is mainly from <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Ukraine" title="Natural gas in Ukraine">gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_Ukraine" title="Coal in Ukraine">coal</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Ukraine" title="Nuclear power in Ukraine">nuclear</a> then oil.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_223-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-223">[219]</a></sup> The coal industry has been disrupted by conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> Most gas and oil is imported, but since 2015 <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy" title="Energy policy">energy policy</a> has prioritised diversifying energy supply.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>About half of <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">electricity generation</a> is nuclear and a quarter coal.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_223-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-223">[219]</a></sup> The largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a> in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant">Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant</a>, is located in Ukraine. <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_subsidies" title="Fossil fuel subsidies">Fossil fuel subsidies</a> were US$2.2 billion in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[311]</a></sup> Until the 2010s all of Ukraine's nuclear fuel came from Russia, but now most does not.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although gas transit is declining, over 40 billion cubic metres (bcm) of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Russia" title="Natural gas in Russia">Russian gas</a> flowed through Ukraine in 2021,<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[313]</a></sup> which was about a third of Russian exports to other European countries.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[314]</a></sup> Some energy infrastructure was destroyed in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[315]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 16 March 2022, <a href="/wiki/European_Network_of_Transmission_System_Operators_for_Electricity" title="European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity">European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity</a> said Ukraine's electricity grid and <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>'s electricity grid were successfully synchronized with the <a href="/wiki/Synchronous_grid_of_Continental_Europe" title="Synchronous grid of Continental Europe">Synchronous grid of Continental Europe</a>, on a trial basis, allowing the countries to decouple their power systems from <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, previously part of the <a href="/wiki/IPS/UPS#IPS" title="IPS/UPS">Integrated Power System</a> that also includes <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cbsnews-ukraine-grid_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbsnews-ukraine-grid-321">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Information_technology">Information technology</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Ukraine#Information_technology" title="Economy of Ukraine">Economy_of_Ukraine Â§ Information_technology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_Ukraine" title="Internet in Ukraine">Internet in Ukraine</a></div>
<p>The internet in the country is robust because it is diverse.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-323">[319]</a></sup> Key officials may use <a href="/wiki/Starlink" title="Starlink">Starlink</a> as backup.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_323-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-323">[319]</a></sup> The IT industry contributed almost 5 per cent to Ukraine's GDP in 2021<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[320]</a></sup> and in 2022 continued both inside and outside the country.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[321]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine" title="Demographics of Ukraine">Demographics of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a></div>
<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">

</div>
<p>Before the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> the country had over 41 million people, and was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">eighth-most populous country</a> in Europe. It is a <a href="/wiki/Urbanization_by_country" title="Urbanization by country">heavily urbanized country</a>, and its industrial regions in the east and southeast are the most densely populatedâabout 67% of its total population lives in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[322]</a></sup> At that time Ukraine had a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population density">population density</a> of 69.5 inhabitants per square kilometre (180 per square mile), and the overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in the country</a> at birth was 73 years (68 years for males and 77.8 years for females).<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, Ukraine's population hit a peak of roughly 52 million in 1993. However, due to its <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> exceeding its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>, mass emigration, poor living conditions, and low-quality health care,<sup id="cite_ref-nw-20260217_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nw-20260217-328">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ukrstat-population_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ukrstat-population-329">[325]</a></sup> the total population decreased by 6.6 million, or 12.8% from the same year to 2014.
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a>, ethnic <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> made up roughly 78% of the population, while <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> were the largest minority, at some 17.3% of the population. Small minority populations included: <a href="/wiki/Belarusians" title="Belarusians">Belarusians</a> (0.6%), <a href="/wiki/Moldovans" title="Moldovans">Moldovans</a> (0.5%), <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> (0.5%), <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a> (0.4%), <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">Hungarians</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Romanians" title="Romanians">Romanians</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a> (0.2%), <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a> (0.2%) and <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> (0.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnic_composition_of_the_population_of_Ukraine,_2001_Census_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnic_composition_of_the_population_of_Ukraine,_2001_Census-2">[2]</a></sup> It was also estimated that there were about 10â40,000 <a href="/wiki/Koreans" title="Koreans">Koreans</a> in Ukraine, who lived mostly in the south of the country, belonging to the historical <a href="/wiki/Koryo-saram" title="Koryo-saram">Koryo-saram</a> group.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[326]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup>
</p><p>Outside the former Soviet Union, the largest source of incoming immigrants in Ukraine's post-independence period was from four Asian countries, namely China, India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-mp_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mp-332">[328]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 2010s 1.4 million Ukrainians were <a href="/wiki/Internally_displaced" class="mw-redirect" title="Internally displaced">internally displaced</a> due to the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas" title="War in Donbas">war in Donbas</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[329]</a></sup> and in early 2022 over 4.1 million fled the country in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine" title="Russian language in Ukraine">Russian language in Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ukraine" title="Languages of Ukraine">Languages of Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">Name of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>According to the constitution, the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">state language</a> of Ukraine is Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-335">[331]</a></sup> Russian is widely spoken, especially in eastern and southern Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_335-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-335">[331]</a></sup> Most native Ukrainian speakers know Russian as a second language.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_335-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-335">[331]</a></sup> Russian was the <i>de facto</i> dominant language of the Soviet Union but Ukrainian also held official status<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> and in the schools of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> learning Ukrainian was mandatory.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_335-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-335">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a href="/wiki/File:UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png/290px-UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png/435px-UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png/580px-UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png 2x" data-file-width="2500" data-file-height="1720"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:UkraineNativeLanguagesCensus2001detailed-en.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><b>Linguistic Map of Ukraine.</b> Majority areas declared for alternative native languages by city, town or village council according to <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a></div></div></div>
<p>Effective in August 2012, <a href="/wiki/Legislation_on_languages_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislation on languages in Ukraine">a new law on regional languages</a> entitled any local language spoken by at least a 10 percent minority be declared official within that area.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> Russian was within weeks of being declared as a regional language in several southern and eastern <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Ukraine" title="Oblasts of Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) and cities.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup> Russian could then be used in the administrative office work and documents of these cities'/oblasts'.<sup id="cite_ref-NewUklang2892012_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewUklang2892012-339">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 23 February 2014, following the <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Parliament">Ukrainian Parliament</a> voted to repeal the law on regional languages, making Ukrainian the sole state language at all levels; however, the repeal was not signed by acting <a href="/wiki/Oleksandr_Turchynov" title="Oleksandr Turchynov">President Turchynov</a> or by President Poroshenko.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> In February 2019, the law allowing for official use of regional languages was found unconstitutional.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[340]</a></sup> According to the Council of Europe, this act fails to achieve fair protection of the <a href="/wiki/Linguistic_rights" title="Linguistic rights">linguistic rights</a> of <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minorities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukrainian is the primary language used in the vast majority of Ukraine (see "Linguistic Map of Ukraine" above.) 67% of Ukrainians speak Ukrainian as their primary language, while 30% speak Russian as their primary language.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[342]</a></sup> In eastern and southern Ukraine, Russian is primarily used in some cities, while Ukrainian is used in rural areas. <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a> is spoken in the <a href="/wiki/Zakarpattia_Oblast" title="Zakarpattia Oblast">Zakarpattia Oblast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unian.info_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unian.info-347">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>For a large part of the Soviet era, the number of Ukrainian speakers declined from generation to generation, and by the mid-1980s, the usage of the Ukrainian language in public life had decreased significantly.<sup id="cite_ref-Shamshur_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shamshur-348">[344]</a></sup> Following independence, the government of Ukraine began restoring the use of the Ukrainian language in schools and government through a policy of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup> Today, most foreign films and TV programs, including Russian ones, are subtitled or dubbed in Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> Ukraine's 2017 <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ukraine" title="Education in Ukraine">education law</a> bars primary education in public schools in grade five and up in any language but Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[349]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Independent_Information_Agency" title="Ukrainian Independent Information Agency">Unian</a></i> reported that "A ban on the use of cultural products, namely movies, books, songs, etc., in the Russian language in the public has been introduced" in the <a href="/wiki/Lviv_Oblast" title="Lviv Oblast">Lviv Oblast</a> in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diaspora">Diaspora</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066933788">.mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}</style><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref">These paragraphs are an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukrainian_diaspora&action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
The <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a> comprises <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> and their descendants who live outside Ukraine around the world, especially those who maintain some kind of connection, even if <a href="/wiki/Ephemerality" title="Ephemerality">ephemeral</a>, to the land of their ancestors and maintain their feeling of Ukrainian national identity within their own local community. The Ukrainian diaspora is found throughout numerous regions worldwide including other <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a> as well as in other countries such as <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Poland" title="Ukrainians in Poland">Poland</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[351]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Americans" title="Ukrainian Americans">the United States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Canadians" title="Ukrainian Canadians">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[353]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Ukraine" title="Religion in Ukraine">Religion in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/220px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/330px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/440px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3498" data-file-height="2647"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sophia%27s_Cathedral,_Kyiv" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv">Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[354]</a></sup> is one of the main Christian cathedrals in Ukraine</div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine has the world's <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy_by_country" title="Eastern Orthodoxy by country">second-largest Eastern Orthodox population</a>, after Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[356]</a></sup> A 2021 survey conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_International_Institute_of_Sociology" title="Kyiv International Institute of Sociology">Kyiv International Institute of Sociology</a> (KIIS) found that 82% of Ukrainians declared themselves to be religious, while 7% were <a href="/wiki/Atheists" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheists">atheists</a>, and a further 11% found it difficult to answer the question.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[357]</a></sup> The level of religiosity in Ukraine was reported to be the highest in <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> (91%), and the lowest in the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> (57%) and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> (56%).<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page27_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page27-362">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, 82% of Ukrainians were Christians; out of which 72.7% declared themselves to be <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a>, 8.8% <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Greek Rite Catholics</a>, 2.3% <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a> and 0.9% <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Christian" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian">Christians</a> comprised 2.3%. <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> were the religions of 0.2% of the population each. According to the KIIS study, roughly 58.3% of the Ukrainian Orthodox population were members of the <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Church_of_Ukraine" title="Orthodox Church of Ukraine">Orthodox Church of Ukraine</a>, and 25.4% were members of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_(Moscow_Patriarchate)" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)">Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2018 survey by the Razumkov Centre, 9.4% of Ukrainians were <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Byzantine Rite Catholics</a> and 0.8% were <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-364">[360]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Protestants_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestants in Ukraine">Protestants</a> are a growing community in Ukraine, who made up 1.9% of the population in 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_364-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-364">[360]</a></sup> but rose to 2.2% of the population in 2018.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Ukraine" title="Health in Ukraine">Health in Ukraine</a></div><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="Ambox current red Asia Australia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290"></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2022</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Ukraine's healthcare system is state subsidised and freely available to all Ukrainian citizens and registered residents. However, it is not compulsory to be treated in a state-run hospital as a number of private medical complexes do exist nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[361]</a></sup> The public sector employs most healthcare professionals, with those working for private medical centres typically also retaining their state employment as they are mandated to provide care at public health facilities on a regular basis.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a Oblast">Poltava Oblast</a></div></div></div>
<p>All of Ukraine's medical service providers and hospitals are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Healthcare_(Ukraine)" title="Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)">Ministry of Healthcare</a>, which provides oversight and scrutiny of general medical practice as well as being responsible for the day-to-day administration of the healthcare system. Despite this, standards of hygiene and patient-care have fallen.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine faces a number of major public health issues and is considered to be in a demographic crisis because of its high death rate and low birth rate (the Ukrainian birth rate is 11 births/1,000 population, and the death rate is 16.3 deaths/1,000 population). A factor contributing to the high death rate is a high <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a> among working-age males from preventable causes such as <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_poisoning" class="mw-redirect" title="Alcohol poisoning">alcohol poisoning</a> and smoking.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank1_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank1-368">[364]</a></sup> In addition, obesity, systemic high blood pressure and the HIV endemic are all major challenges facing the Ukrainian healthcare system.
</p><p>Active reformation of Ukraine's healthcare system was initiated right after the appointment of <a href="/wiki/Ulana_Suprun" title="Ulana Suprun">Ulana Suprun</a> as a head of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Healthcare_(Ukraine)" title="Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)">Ministry of Healthcare</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rada_Reform_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rada_Reform-369">[365]</a></sup> Assisted by deputy Pavlo Kovtoniuk, Suprun first changed the distribution of finances in healthcare.<sup id="cite_ref-Kovtoniuk_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kovtoniuk-370">[366]</a></sup> Funds must follow the patient. General practitioners will provide basic care for patients. The patient will have the right to choose one. Emergency medical service is considered to be fully funded by the state. <a href="/wiki/Emergency_Medicine_Reform_in_Ukraine_since_2016" class="mw-redirect" title="Emergency Medicine Reform in Ukraine since 2016">Emergency Medicine Reform</a> is also an important part of the healthcare reform. In addition, patients who suffer from chronic diseases, which cause a high toll of disability and mortality, are provided with free or low-price medicine.<sup id="cite_ref-Drugs_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drugs-371">[367]</a></sup>
</p>

Dalmatian Metropolitans">Residence of Bukovinian and Dalmatian Metropolitans</a> by <a href="/wiki/Josef_Hl%C3%A1vka" title="Josef HlÃ¡vka">Josef HlÃ¡vka</a>, 1882, now <a href="/wiki/Chernivtsi_University" title="Chernivtsi University">Chernivtsi University</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Ukrainian constitution</a>, access to free education is granted to all citizens. Complete general secondary education is compulsory in the state schools which constitute the overwhelming majority. Free higher education in state and communal educational establishments is provided on a competitive basis.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of the Soviet Union's emphasis on total access of education for all citizens, which continues today, the <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> is an estimated 99.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_49-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-49">[45]</a></sup> Since 2005, an eleven-year school programme has been replaced with a twelve-year one: primary education takes four years to complete (starting at age six), middle education (secondary) takes five years to complete; upper secondary then takes three years.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[369]</a></sup> Students in the 12th grade take Government tests, which are also referred to as school-leaving exams. These tests are later used for university admissions.
</p><p>Among the oldest is also the <a href="/wiki/Lviv_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Lviv University">Lviv University</a>, founded in 1661. More higher education institutions were set up in the 19th century, beginning with universities in <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Kharkiv University">Kharkiv</a> (1805), <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko_National_University_of_Kyiv" title="Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (1834), <a href="/wiki/Odessa_University" title="Odessa University">Odessa</a> (1865) and <a href="/wiki/Chernivtsi_University" title="Chernivtsi University">Chernivtsi</a> (1875) and a number of professional higher education institutions, e.g.: <a href="/wiki/Nizhyn_Pedagogical_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Nizhyn Pedagogical University">Nizhyn Historical and Philological Institute</a> (originally established as the Gymnasium of Higher Sciences in 1805), a Veterinary Institute (1873) and a <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_Polytechnical_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="Kharkiv Polytechnical Institute">Technological Institute</a> (1885) in <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky_Kyiv_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute">Polytechnic Institute</a> in Kyiv (1898) and a Higher Mining School (1899) in <a href="/wiki/Dnipro" title="Dnipro">Katerynoslav</a>. Rapid growth followed in the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Soviet</a> period. By 1988 the number of higher education institutions increased to 146 with over 850,000 students.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ukrainian higher education system comprises higher educational establishments, <a href="/wiki/Scientific" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientific">scientific</a> and <a href="/wiki/Methodological" class="mw-redirect" title="Methodological">methodological</a> facilities under national, <a href="/wiki/Municipal_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipal government">municipal</a> and self-governing bodies in charge of education.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[371]</a></sup> The organisation of higher education in Ukraine is built up in accordance with the structure of education of the world's higher <a href="/wiki/Developed_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developed countries">developed countries</a>, as is defined by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> and the UN.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[372]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">post-secondary graduates</a> in Europe, while being ranked seventh in population.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Ukraine" title="Higher education in Ukraine">Higher education</a> is either state funded or private. Most universities provide subsidised housing for out-of-city students. It is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. Ukrainian universities confer two degrees: the bachelor's degree (4 years) and the master's degree (5â6th year), in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_process" class="mw-redirect" title="Bologna process">Bologna process</a>. Historically, <a href="/wiki/Specialist_degree" title="Specialist degree">Specialist degree</a> (usually 5 years) is still also granted; it was the only degree awarded by universities in Soviet times.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[374]</a></sup> Ukraine was ranked 49th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_differences">Regional differences</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine#Regional_differences" title="Demographics of Ukraine">Demographics of Ukraine Â§ Regional differences</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine" title="Southern Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png/290px-Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="202" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png/435px-Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png/580px-Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png 2x" data-file-width="817" data-file-height="570"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ukr_elections_2014_multimandate_okruhs.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The results of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election">2014 parliamentary election</a> with <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Front_(Ukraine)" title="People's Front (Ukraine)">People's Front</a> in yellow, <a href="/wiki/Opposition_Bloc" title="Opposition Bloc">Opposition Bloc</a> in blue and <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko_Bloc" class="mw-redirect" title="Petro Poroshenko Bloc">Petro Poroshenko Bloc</a> in red</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> is the dominant language in <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> is the dominant language in the cities of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine" title="Southern Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> schools, learning <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> was mandatory; in modern Ukraine, schools with Ukrainian as the language of instruction offer classes in Russian and in the other minority languages.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_335-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-335">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RatingJuly12_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RatingJuly12-381">[377]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine" title="Russian language in Ukraine">Russian language</a>, on <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_nationalism" title="Ukrainian nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a>, opinion in Eastern Ukraine and Southern Ukraine tends to be the exact opposite of those in Western Ukraine; while opinions in Central Ukraine on these topics tend be less extreme.<sup id="cite_ref-RatingJuly12_381-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RatingJuly12-381">[377]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KIISS1313_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KIISS1313-385">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>Similar historical cleavages also remain evident at the level of individual social identification. Attitudes toward the most important political issue, relations with Russia, differed strongly between <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>, identifying more with <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_nationalism" title="Ukrainian nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, predominantly Russian orientated and favourable to the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet era">Soviet era</a>, while in central and southern Ukraine, as well as <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, such divisions were less important and there was less antipathy toward people from other regions (a poll by the <a href="/wiki/Research_%26_Branding_Group" title="Research & Branding Group">Research & Branding Group</a> held March 2010 showed that the attitude of the citizens of Donetsk to the citizens of Lviv was 79% positive and that the attitude of the citizens of Lviv to the citizens of Donetsk was 88% positive).<sup id="cite_ref-antipathy_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antipathy-386">[382]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, all were united by an overarching Ukrainian identity based on shared economic difficulties, showing that other attitudes are determined more by culture and politics than by demographic differences.<sup id="cite_ref-antipathy_386-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antipathy-386">[382]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> Surveys of regional identities in Ukraine have shown that the feeling of belonging to a "Soviet identity" is strongest in the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> (about 40%) and the Crimea (about 30%).<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine" title="Elections in Ukraine">elections</a> voters of Western and Central Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Ukraine" title="Oblasts of Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) vote mostly for parties (<a href="/wiki/Our_Ukraine%E2%80%93People%27s_Self-Defense_Bloc" title="Our UkraineâPeople's Self-Defense Bloc">Our Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/All-Ukrainian_Union_%22Fatherland%22" class="mw-redirect" title="All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"">Batkivshchyna</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[386]</a></sup> and presidential candidates (<a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yuschenko" class="mw-redirect" title="Viktor Yuschenko">Viktor Yuschenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a>) with a <a href="/wiki/Pro-Western" class="mw-redirect" title="Pro-Western">pro-Western</a> and state reform <a href="/wiki/Political_platform" class="mw-redirect" title="Political platform">platform</a>, while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts vote for parties (<a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Ukraine" title="Communist Party of Ukraine">CPU</a>, <a href="/wiki/Party_of_Regions" title="Party of Regions">Party of Regions</a>) and presidential candidates (<a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>) with a <a href="/wiki/Pro-Russian" class="mw-redirect" title="Pro-Russian">pro-Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Status_quo" title="Status quo">status quo</a> platform.<sup id="cite_ref-EWparties_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWparties-391">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Umland_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Umland-392">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> However, this geographical division is decreasing.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[392]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Ukraine" title="List of cities in Ukraine">List of cities in Ukraine</a></div>
<p>In total, Ukraine has 457 cities, 176 of them are labelled oblast-class, 279 smaller <span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn">raion</i></span>-class cities, and two special legal status cities. These are followed by 886 urban-type settlements and 28,552 villages.<sup id="cite_ref-oblasts_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oblasts-398">[394]</a></sup>
</p>
