<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_culture" title="Ukrainian culture">Ukrainian culture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pysanky2011.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/220px-Pysanky2011.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/330px-Pysanky2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/440px-Pysanky2011.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3250" data-file-height="2224"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pysanky2011.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A collection of traditional Ukrainian Easter eggsâ<a href="/wiki/Pysanka" title="Pysanka">pysanky</a>. The design motifs on pysanky date back to early Slavic cultures.</div></div></div>
<p>Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Christianity">Orthodox Christianity</a>, the dominant religion in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup> Gender roles also tend to be more traditional, and grandparents play a greater role in bringing up children, than in the West.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> The culture of Ukraine has also been influenced by its eastern and western neighbours, reflected in its <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_architecture" title="Ukrainian architecture">architecture</a>, music and art.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Communist era had quite a strong effect on the art and writing of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[398]</a></sup> In 1932, Stalin made <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a> state policy in the Soviet Union when he promulgated the decree "On the Reconstruction of Literary and Art Organisations". This greatly stifled creativity. During the 1980s <a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a> (openness) was introduced and Soviet artists and writers again became free to express themselves as they wanted.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukraine&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> inscribed <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Ukraine" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Ukraine">seven properties in Ukraine on the World Heritage List</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> Ukraine is also known for its decorative and folk traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Petrykivka_painting" title="Petrykivka painting">Petrykivka painting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosiv" title="Kosiv">Kosiv</a> ceramics, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cossack%27s_songs_of_Dnipropetrovsk_Region&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Cossack's songs of Dnipropetrovsk Region (page does not exist)">Cossack songs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup>
</p><p>The tradition of the <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg" title="Easter egg">Easter egg</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Pysanky" class="mw-redirect" title="Pysanky">pysanky</a>, has long roots in Ukraine. These eggs were drawn on with wax to create a pattern; then, the dye was applied to give the eggs their pleasant colours, the dye did not affect the previously wax-coated parts of the egg. After the entire egg was dyed, the wax was removed leaving only the colourful pattern. This tradition is thousands of years old, and precedes the arrival of Christianity to Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[404]</a></sup> In the city of <a href="/wiki/Kolomyia" title="Kolomyia">Kolomyia</a> near the foothills of the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a>, the museum of Pysanka was built in 2000 and won a nomination as the monument of modern Ukraine in 2007, part of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> action.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_literature" title="Ukrainian literature">Ukrainian literature</a></div>
<p>Technically the history of Ukrainian literature dates all of the way back to the 11th century, following the Christianisation of Kievan Rus', however these earliest writings were <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgical</a> and were written in the <a href="/wiki/Old_Church_Slavonic" title="Old Church Slavonic">Old Church Slavonic</a> language, not in true Ukrainian. Historical accounts of the time were referred to as <i><a href="/wiki/Chronicle" title="Chronicle">chronicles</a></i>, the most significant of which was the <a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-409">[405]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-410">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_Gnone"><a href="#endnote_Gnone">[g]</a></sup> Literary activity faced a sudden decline during the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus'">Mongol invasion of Rus'</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_409-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-409">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/147px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="194" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/221px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/294px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1517" data-file-height="2006"></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a>, self-portrait</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg/274px-%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg 2x" data-file-width="560" data-file-height="800"></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Lesya_Ukrainka" title="Lesya Ukrainka">Lesya Ukrainka</a>, one of the foremost Ukrainian women writers</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Ukrainian literature again began to develop in the 14th century, and was advanced significantly in the 16th century with the invention of the <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">printing press</a> and with the beginning of the Cossack era, under both Russian and Polish dominance.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_409-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-409">[405]</a></sup> The Cossacks established an independent society and popularized a <a href="/wiki/Duma_(epic)" title="Duma (epic)">new kind</a> of <a href="/wiki/Epic_poem" class="mw-redirect" title="Epic poem">epic poems</a>, which marked a high point of Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Oral_literature" title="Oral literature">oral literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_410-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-410">[406]</a></sup> These advances were then set back in the 17th and early 18th centuries, when publishing in the Ukrainian language was outlawed. Nonetheless, by the late 18th century modern literary Ukrainian finally emerged.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_409-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-409">[405]</a></sup> In 1798 the modern era of the Ukrainian literary tradition began with <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kotlyarevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Kotlyarevsky">Ivan Kotlyarevsky</a>'s publication of <a href="/wiki/Eneida" title="Eneida">Eneida</a> in the Ukrainian vernacular.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 1830s, a Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">romantic literature</a> began to develop, and the nation's most renowned cultural figure, romanticist poet-painter <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> emerged. Whereas Ivan Kotliarevsky is considered to be the father of literature in the Ukrainian vernacular; Shevchenko is the father of a national revival.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>Then, in 1863, the use of the Ukrainian language in print was effectively <a href="/wiki/Ems_Ukaz" title="Ems Ukaz">prohibited</a> by the Russian Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-censor_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censor-72">[68]</a></sup> This severely curtailed literary activity in the area, and Ukrainian writers were forced to either publish their works in Russian or release them in Austrian controlled <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a>. The ban was never officially lifted, but it became obsolete after the revolution and the Bolsheviks' coming to power.<sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_410-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-410">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukrainian literature continued to flourish in the early Soviet years when nearly all literary trends were approved (the most important literary figures of that time were <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Khvylovy" title="Mykola Khvylovy">Mykola Khvylovy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valerian_Pidmohylny" title="Valerian Pidmohylny">Valerian Pidmohylny</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Kulish" title="Mykola Kulish">Mykola Kulish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mykhayl_Semenko" class="mw-redirect" title="Mykhayl Semenko">Mykhayl Semenko</a> and some others). These policies faced a steep decline in the 1930s, when prominent representatives as well as many others were killed by the <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">NKVD</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>. In general around 223 writers were repressed by what was known as the <a href="/wiki/Executed_Renaissance" title="Executed Renaissance">Executed Renaissance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup> These repressions were part of Stalin's implemented policy of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a>. The doctrine did not necessarily repress the use of the Ukrainian language, but it required that writers follow a certain style in their works.
</p><p>In post-Stalinist times literary activities continued to be somewhat limited under the Communist Party. The most famous figures of Ukrainian post-war Soviet literature were <a href="/wiki/Lina_Kostenko" title="Lina Kostenko">Lina Kostenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmytro_Pavlychko" title="Dmytro Pavlychko">Dmytro Pavlychko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borys_Oliynyk_(poet)" title="Borys Oliynyk (poet)">Borys Oliynyk (poet)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Drach" title="Ivan Drach">Ivan Drach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oles_Honchar" title="Oles Honchar">Oles Honchar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Stus" title="Vasyl Stus">Vasyl Stus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Symonenko" title="Vasyl Symonenko">Vasyl Symonenko</a>.
</p><p>Literary freedom grew in the late 1980s and early 1990s alongside the decline and collapse of the USSR and the reestablishment of Ukrainian independence in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_409-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-409">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_architecture" title="Ukrainian architecture">Ukrainian architecture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/220px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/330px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/440px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5400" data-file-height="3600"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Cathedral" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Michael's Golden-Domed Cathedral">St. Michael's Golden-Domed Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, foremost example of <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Cossack Baroque">Cossack Baroque</a> and one of Ukraine's most recognizable landmarks</div></div></div>
<p>Ukrainian architecture includes the motifs and styles that are found in structures built in modern Ukraine, and by <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> worldwide.
These include initial roots which were established in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Slavs" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Slavs">Eastern Slavic</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus'">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a> for several ages Ukrainian architecture was influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus">12th century</a>, the distinct <a href="/wiki/Architectural_history" class="mw-redirect" title="Architectural history">architectural history</a> continued in the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia-Volhynia" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Galicia-Volhynia">Kingdom of Galicia-Volhynia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KatchanovskiKohutNebesio2013_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KatchanovskiKohutNebesio2013-414">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the union with the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>, architecture in Ukraine began to develop in different directions, with many structures in the larger eastern, Russian-ruled area built in the styles of <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a> of that period, whilst the western region of <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a> developed under <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Poland" title="Architecture of Poland">Polish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Austria">Austro-Hungarian architectural influences</a>. Ukrainian national motifs would eventually be used during the period of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and in modern independent Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-KatchanovskiKohutNebesio2013_414-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KatchanovskiKohutNebesio2013-414">[410]</a></sup> A major project, which may take up most of the 21st century, is the construction of the Kyiv City-Centre on the <a href="/wiki/Rybalskyi_Peninsula" title="Rybalskyi Peninsula">Rybalskyi Peninsula</a>, which, when finished, will include a dense skyscraper park amid the picturesque landscape of the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gradsovet_05_12_07_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gradsovet_05_12_07-415">[411]</a></sup> However, much of the contemporary architectural skyline of Ukraine is dominated by Soviet-style <a href="/wiki/Khrushchyovka" title="Khrushchyovka">Khrushchyovkas</a>, or low-cost apartment buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Weaving_and_embroidery">Weaving and embroidery</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/220px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/330px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/440px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rushnyk" title="Rushnyk">Rushnyk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_embroidery" title="Ukrainian embroidery">Ukrainian embroidery</a></div></div></div>
<p>Artisan <a href="/wiki/Textile_arts" title="Textile arts">textile arts</a> play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> especially in <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_wedding_traditions" title="Ukrainian wedding traditions">Ukrainian wedding traditions</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_embroidery" title="Ukrainian embroidery">Ukrainian embroidery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> and lace-making are used in traditional <a href="/wiki/Folk_dress" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk dress">folk dress</a> and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colours and types of stitches.<sup id="cite_ref-museum_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-museum-419">[415]</a></sup> Use of colour is very important and has roots in <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_folklore" title="Ukrainian folklore">Ukrainian folklore</a>. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the <a href="/wiki/Rushnyk" title="Rushnyk">Rushnyk</a> Museum in <a href="/wiki/Pereiaslav" title="Pereiaslav">Pereiaslav</a>.
</p><p>National dress is woven and highly decorated. Weaving with handmade looms is still practised in the village of Krupove, situated in <a href="/wiki/Rivne_Oblast" title="Rivne Oblast">Rivne Oblast</a>. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts fabrication. Nina Myhailivna<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[416]</a></sup> and Uliana Petrivna<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup> with international recognition.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ukraine" title="Music of Ukraine">Music of Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_(4).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/220px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/330px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/440px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4737" data-file-height="5125"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_(4).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Cossack_Mamay" title="Cossack Mamay">Cossack Mamay</a> playing a <a href="/wiki/Kobza" title="Kobza">kobza</a></div></div></div>
<p>Music is a major part of Ukrainian culture, with a long history and many influences. From traditional <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modern_rock" title="Modern rock">modern rock</a>, Ukraine has produced several internationally recognised musicians including <a href="/wiki/Kirill_Karabits" title="Kirill Karabits">Kirill Karabits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Okean_Elzy" title="Okean Elzy">Okean Elzy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ruslana" title="Ruslana">Ruslana</a>. Elements from traditional Ukrainian folk music made their way into Western music and even into modern <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>. Ukrainian music sometimes presents a perplexing mix of exotic melismatic singing with chordal harmony. The most striking general characteristic of authentic ethnic Ukrainian folk music is the wide use of minor modes or keys which incorporate augmented second intervals.<sup id="cite_ref-Sonevytsky_2019_p._422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sonevytsky_2019_p.-422">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Baroque period, music had a place of considerable importance in the curriculum of the <a href="/wiki/Kyiv-Mohyla_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyiv-Mohyla Academy">Kyiv-Mohyla Academy</a>. Much of the nobility was well versed in music with many Ukrainian Cossack leaders such as (<a href="/wiki/Ivan_Mazepa" title="Ivan Mazepa">Mazepa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semen_Paliy" title="Semen Paliy">Paliy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antin_Holovaty" title="Antin Holovaty">Holovatyj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Sirko" title="Ivan Sirko">Sirko</a>) being accomplished players of the <a href="/wiki/Kobza" title="Kobza">kobza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bandura" title="Bandura">bandura</a> or <a href="/wiki/Torban" title="Torban">torban</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="222" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="377" data-file-height="493"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mykola_Lysenko" title="Mykola Lysenko">Mykola Lysenko</a> is widely considered to be the father of Ukrainian classical music<sup id="cite_ref-Risch_2011_p._44_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Risch_2011_p._44-423">[419]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The first dedicated musical academy was set up in <a href="/wiki/Hlukhiv" title="Hlukhiv">Hlukhiv</a> in 1738 and students were taught to sing and play violin and bandura from manuscripts. As a result, many of the earliest composers and performers within the Russian empire were ethnically Ukrainian, having been born or educated in Hlukhiv or having been closely associated with this music school.<sup id="cite_ref-Struk_1993_p._1461_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Struk_1993_p._1461-424">[420]</a></sup> Ukrainian classical music differs considerably depending on whether the composer was of Ukrainian ethnicity living in Ukraine, a composer of non-Ukrainian ethnicity who was a citizen of Ukraine, or part of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ukrainian_people_2017_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ukrainian_people_2017-425">[421]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the mid-1960s, Western-influenced pop music has been growing in popularity in Ukraine. Folk singer and harmonium player <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Sadovska" title="Mariana Sadovska">Mariana Sadovska</a> is prominent. Ukrainian pop and folk music arose with the international popularity of groups and performers like <a href="/wiki/Vopli_Vidoplyasova" class="mw-redirect" title="Vopli Vidoplyasova">Vopli Vidoplyasova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakh_Daughters" title="Dakh Daughters">Dakh Daughters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakha_Brakha" class="mw-redirect" title="Dakha Brakha">Dakha Brakha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Dorn" title="Ivan Dorn">Ivan Dorn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Okean_Elzy" title="Okean Elzy">Okean Elzy</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Ukraine">Media of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven.<sup id="cite_ref-FH_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FH-426">[422]</a></sup> The constitution and laws provide for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a><sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press_in_Ukraine" title="Freedom of the press in Ukraine">press</a>. However, the government does not always respect these rights in practice.<sup id="cite_ref-USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-20122_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-20122-428">[424]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="old (March 2022)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The main regulatory authority for the broadcast media is the <a href="/wiki/National_Television_and_Radio_Broadcasting_Council_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="National Television and Radio Broadcasting Council of Ukraine">National Television and Radio Broadcasting Council of Ukraine</a> (NTRBCU), tasked with licensing media outlets and ensure their compliance with the law.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> dominates the media sector in Ukraine: National <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Ukraine" title="List of newspapers in Ukraine">newspapers</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Den_(newspaper)" class="mw-redirect" title="Den (newspaper)">Den</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dzerkalo_Tyzhnia" title="Dzerkalo Tyzhnia">Dzerkalo Tyzhnia</a></i>, tabloids, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ukrainian_Week" title="The Ukrainian Week">The Ukrainian Week</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Focus_(Ukrainian_magazine)" title="Focus (Ukrainian magazine)">Focus</a></i>, and television and radio are largely based there,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> although <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a> is also a significant national media centre. The National News Agency of Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Ukrinform" title="Ukrinform">Ukrinform</a> was founded here in 1918. The Ukrainian publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (March 2022)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Sanoma" title="Sanoma">Sanoma</a> publishes Ukrainian editions of such magazines as <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harpers_Bazaar" class="mw-redirect" title="Harpers Bazaar">Harpers Bazaar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="National Geographic Magazine">National Geographic Magazine</a></i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/BBC_Ukrainian" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC Ukrainian">BBC Ukrainian</a> started its broadcasts in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukraine&action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 75% of the population use the internet, and social media is widely used by government and people.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Ukraine" title="Sport in Ukraine">Sport in Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/220px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/330px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/440px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg 2x" data-file-width="656" data-file-height="440"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ukrainian footballer <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko" title="Andriy Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a> celebrates a goal against Sweden at Euro 2012</div></div></div>
<p>Ukraine greatly benefited from the Soviet emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Physical_education" title="Physical education">physical education</a>. These policies left Ukraine with hundreds of stadia, swimming pools, gymnasia and many other athletic facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> The most popular sport is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. The top professional league is the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Premier_League" title="Ukrainian Premier League">Vyscha Liha</a> ("premier league").
</p><p>Many Ukrainians also played for the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet national football team">Soviet national football team</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or" title="Ballon d'Or">Ballon d'Or</a> winners <a href="/wiki/Ihor_Belanov" class="mw-redirect" title="Ihor Belanov">Ihor Belanov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oleh_Blokhin" class="mw-redirect" title="Oleh Blokhin">Oleh Blokhin</a>. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko" title="Andriy Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a>. The national team made its debut in the <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a>, and reached the quarterfinals before losing to eventual champions, <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">Italy</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VladimirVitaliy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/170px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/255px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/340px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="800"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:VladimirVitaliy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vitali_Klitschko" title="Vitali Klitschko">Vitali Klitschko</a> and his brother, <a href="/wiki/Wladimir_Klitschko" title="Wladimir Klitschko">Wladimir</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxers</a> are amongst the best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup> Since becoming the undisputed cruiserweight champion in 2018, <a href="/wiki/Oleksandr_Usyk" title="Oleksandr Usyk">Oleksandr Usyk</a> has also gone on to win the unified WBA (Super), IBF, WBO and IBO heavyweight titles. This feat made him one of only three boxers to have unified the cruiserweight world titles and become a world heavyweight champion.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[430]</a></sup> The brothers <a href="/wiki/Vitali_Klitschko" title="Vitali Klitschko">Vitali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wladimir_Klitschko" title="Wladimir Klitschko">Wladimir Klitschko</a> are former <a href="/wiki/Heavyweight" title="Heavyweight">heavyweight</a> world champions who held multiple world titles throughout their careers. Also hailing from Ukraine is <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Lomachenko" class="mw-redirect" title="Vasyl Lomachenko">Vasyl Lomachenko</a>, a <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_Olympic_games" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 Olympic games">2012 Olympic</a> gold medalist. He is the <a href="/wiki/Unified_champion" class="mw-redirect" title="Unified champion">unified</a> <a href="/wiki/Lightweight" title="Lightweight">lightweight</a> world champion who ties the record for winning a world title in the fewest professional fights; three. As of September 2018, he is ranked as the world's best active boxer, <a href="/wiki/Pound_for_pound" title="Pound for pound">pound for pound</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Boxing_pound_for_pound_rankings#ESPN" title="Boxing pound for pound rankings">ESPN</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sergey_Bubka" title="Sergey Bubka">Sergey Bubka</a> held the record in the <a href="/wiki/Pole_vault" title="Pole vault">Pole vault</a> from 1993 to 2014; with great strength, speed and gymnastic abilities, he was voted the world's best athlete on several occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[432]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[433]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is becoming popular in Ukraine. In 2011, Ukraine was granted a right to organize <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2015" title="EuroBasket 2015">EuroBasket 2015</a>. Two years later the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukraine national basketball team">Ukraine national basketball team</a> finished sixth in <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2013" title="EuroBasket 2013">EuroBasket 2013</a> and qualified to <a href="/wiki/2014_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup" title="2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup">FIBA World Cup</a> for the first time in its history. <a href="/wiki/Euroleague" class="mw-redirect" title="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> participant <a href="/wiki/BC_Budivelnyk" title="BC Budivelnyk">Budivelnyk Kyiv</a> is the strongest professional basketball club in Ukraine.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is a popular sport in Ukraine. <a href="/wiki/Ruslan_Ponomariov" title="Ruslan Ponomariov">Ruslan Ponomariov</a> is the former world champion. There are about 85 <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">Grandmasters</a> and 198 <a href="/wiki/International_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="International Masters">International Masters</a> in Ukraine.<a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a> is played throughout Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[434]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_cuisine" title="Ukrainian cuisine">Ukrainian cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wareniki.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/220px-Wareniki.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/330px-Wareniki.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/440px-Wareniki.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3328" data-file-height="1872"></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Wareniki.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Varenyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Varenyky">Varenyky</a> topped with fried onion</div></div></div>
<p>The traditional Ukrainian diet includes chicken, pork, beef, fish and mushrooms. Ukrainians also tend to eat a lot of potatoes, grains, fresh, boiled or pickled vegetables. Popular traditional dishes <i><span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Varenyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Varenyky">varenyky</a></i></span></i> (boiled dumplings with mushrooms, potatoes, sauerkraut, cottage cheese, cherries or berries), <i><a href="/wiki/Nalysnyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nalysnyky">nalysnyky</a></i> (pancakes with cottage cheese, poppy seeds, mushrooms, caviar or meat), <i><a href="/wiki/Cabbage_soup" title="Cabbage soup">kapusnyak</a></i> (cabbage soup made with meat, potatoes, carrots, onions, millet, tomato paste, spices and fresh herbs), <a href="/wiki/Borscht" title="Borscht">borscht</a> (soup made of beets, cabbage and mushrooms or meat) and <span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Go%C5%82%C4%85bki" title="GoÅÄbki">holubtsy</a></i></span> (stuffed cabbage rolls filled with rice, carrots, onion and minced meat).<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[435]</a></sup> Among traditional baked goods are decorated <a href="/wiki/Korovai" title="Korovai">korovais</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paska_(bread)" title="Paska (bread)">paska Easter bread</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[436]</a></sup> Ukrainian specialties also include <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_cake" title="Kyiv cake">Kyiv cake</a>.
</p><p>Ukrainians drink <a href="/wiki/Kompot" title="Kompot">stewed fruit compote</a>, juices, milk, buttermilk, mineral water, tea and coffee, beer, wine and <span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Horilka" title="Horilka">horilka</a></i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1054258005">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul li{list-style:none}@media(max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{padding-left:1.6em;text-indent:-1.6em}}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="refbegin refbegin-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 30em">
<p><b>a.</b><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1041539562">.mw-parser-output .citation{word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}</style><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Anone"><a href="#ref_Anone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span>  Among the Ukrainians that rose to the highest offices in the Russian Empire were <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_Razumovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksey Razumovsky">Aleksey Razumovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Bezborodko" title="Alexander Bezborodko">Alexander Bezborodko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Paskevich" title="Ivan Paskevich">Ivan Paskevich</a>. Among the Ukrainians who greatly influenced the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> in this period were <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Yavorsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Stephen Yavorsky">Stephen Yavorsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feofan_Prokopovich" class="mw-redirect" title="Feofan Prokopovich">Feofan Prokopovich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dimitry_of_Rostov" title="Dimitry of Rostov">Dimitry of Rostov</a>.
</p><p><b>b.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Bnone"><a href="#ref_Bnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span>  Estimates on the number of deaths vary. Official Soviet data is not available because the Soviet government denied the existence of the famine. See the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> article for details. Sources differ on interpreting various statements from different branches of different governments as to whether they amount to the official recognition of the Famine as Genocide by the country. For example, after the statement issued by the Latvian Sejm on 13 March 2008, the total number of countries is given as 19 (according to <i>Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a></i>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/domestic/story/2008/03/080313_latvia_holodomor_oh.shtml"><span title="Ukrainian-language text"><span lang="uk">"ÐÐ°ÑÐ²ÑÑ Ð²Ð¸Ð·Ð½Ð°Ð»Ð° ÐÐ¾Ð»Ð¾Ð´Ð¾Ð¼Ð¾Ñ ÒÐµÐ½Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð´Ð¾Ð¼"</span></span></a>), 16 (according to <i><a href="/wiki/Korrespondent" title="Korrespondent">Korrespondent</a></i>, Russian edition: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/politics/403002"><span title="Russian-language text"><span lang="ru">"ÐÐ¾ÑÐ»Ðµ Ð¿ÑÐ¾Ð´Ð¾Ð»Ð¶Ð¸ÑÐµÐ»ÑÐ½ÑÑ Ð´ÐµÐ±Ð°ÑÐ¾Ð² Ð¡ÐµÐ¹Ð¼ ÐÐ°ÑÐ²Ð¸Ð¸ Ð¿ÑÐ¸Ð·Ð½Ð°Ð» ÐÐ¾Ð»Ð¾Ð´Ð¾Ð¼Ð¾Ñ Ð³ÐµÐ½Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð´Ð¾Ð¼ ÑÐºÑÐ°Ð¸Ð½ÑÐµÐ²"</span></span></a>), "more than 10" (according to <i>Korrespondent</i>, Ukrainian edition: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ua.korrespondent.net/ukraine/403780-latviya-viznala-golodomor-1932-33-rr-genocidom-ukrayinciv"><span title="Ukrainian-language text"><span lang="uk">"ÐÐ°ÑÐ²ÑÑ Ð²Ð¸Ð·Ð½Ð°Ð»Ð° ÐÐ¾Ð»Ð¾Ð´Ð¾Ð¼Ð¾Ñ 1932â33 ÑÑ. Ð³ÐµÐ½Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð´Ð¾Ð¼ ÑÐºÑÐ°ÑÐ½ÑÑÐ²"</span></span></a>) Retrieved 27 January 2008.
</p><p><b>c.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_C1"><a href="#ref_C1"><b><sup>1</sup></b></a></span> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_C2"><a href="#ref_C2"><b><sup>2</sup></b></a></span>  These figures are likely to be much higher, as they <b>do not</b> include Ukrainians of other nationalities or Ukrainian Jews, but only <a href="/wiki/Ethnic" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic">ethnic</a> Ukrainians, from the Ukrainian SSR.
</p><p><b>d.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Dnone"><a href="#ref_Dnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span>  This figure excludes <a href="/wiki/POW" class="mw-redirect" title="POW">POW</a> deaths.
</p><p><b>e.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Enone"><a href="#ref_Enone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span>  Several countries with territory in Europe have a larger total area, but all of those also include territory outside of Europe. Only Russia's European territory is larger than Ukraine.
</p><p><b>f.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F1"><a href="#ref_F1"><b><sup>1</sup></b></a></span> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F2"><a href="#ref_F2"><b><sup>2</sup></b></a></span> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F3"><a href="#ref_F3"><b><sup>3</sup></b></a></span>  According to the official <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a> data (by nationality;<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup> by language<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup>) about 75 percent of Kyiv's population responded 'Ukrainian' to the native language (ridna mova) census question, and roughly 25 percent responded 'Russian'. On the other hand, when the question 'What language do you use in everyday life?' was asked in the 2003 sociological survey, the Kyivans' answers were distributed as follows: 'mostly Russian': 52 percent, 'both Russian and Ukrainian in equal measure': 32 percent, 'mostly Ukrainian': 14 percent, 'exclusively Ukrainian': 4.3 percent.<br><style </p><p><b>g.</b><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Gnone"><a href="#ref_Gnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span>  Such writings were also the base for Russian and Belarusian literature.
</p>
</div>
